rewrite_text: Star-forming dwarf galaxies (SFDGs) are crucial structures in the early phases of galaxy formation. These small systems excel in their capability to give rise to galaxies, making them exceptional laboratories for exploring the initial conditions of galaxy evolution. In this paper, we present imaging spectroscopy and spatially resolved analysis of 12 SFDGs. We assess oxygen abundances and elemental abundance patterns using both direct techniques and strong line methods. Furthermore, we examine the spatial distribution of chemical elements and investigate the relationships among various variables. Our key findings can be summarized as follows: 1. We identified extremely low oxygen abundances, with higher values of 12 + log (O/H) derived from the R23 method compared to the weak line model proposed by Pettini & Pagel (2004). 2. We found no correlation between oxygen abundances and kinematic transverse velocities. 3. Calcium concentrations appear to decrease with increasing diameter, while iron and aluminum abundances seem to increase at greater distances from the centers. 4. No correlation was found between chemical abundances and the physical properties of the galaxies; however, we did observe a correlation between star formation rates (SFR) and material abundances. Additionally, we discovered a significant fraction of star-forming regions with 12 + log (O/H) values below 8.2, a threshold commonly used by researchers to differentiate between normal and low-metallicity areas.

original_text: Orbital-Free Density Functional Theory (OF-DFT) is an approach to electronic structure theory that combines the advantages of local density and wavefunction-based theories. The theory is formally obtained from conventional Density Functional Theory (DFT) by partitioning the total energy into a linear combination of local energy functionals, each depending on the density and one additional parameter. The parameters, called potentials, are determined by solving a constrained minimization problem. Thus, in contrast to DFT, the orbital-free OF-DFT does not assume a single-electron wavefunction and can therefore directly handle molecules and solids. We provide an implementation of the theory based on a numerical implementation of the Schrödinger equation in Lagrangian form. The theory is validated on molecules and solids and shown to give excellent results for several test cases. Finally, we present a case study of graphene on Au(111), where we find that interaction-induced physis and chemisn plays a significant role in determining the structures.
watermark_text: Orbital - Free Density Functional Theory ( OF - DFT ) is an proposal to electronic structure theoretical that combines the advantages of local density and wavefunction - based theories . The theory is fully obtained from standard Density Functional Theory ( DFT ) by partitioning the total energy into a linear mixture of local power functionals , each varying on the density and one additional parameter .The parameters , called potentials , are decided by solving a constrained minimization problem . Thus , in comparison to DFT , the orbital - free OF - DFT does not assume a single - ion wavefunction and can thus effectively handle molecules and solids .We provide an implementation of the principle relying on a numerical formulation of the Schrödinger equation in Lagrangian form . The theory is validated on molecules and solids and demonstrated to give good results for numerous test situations .Finally , we present a case study of graphene on Au ( 111 ) , where we find that interaction - mediated physis and chemisn plays a major part in identifying the structures .
rewrite_text: Orbital-Free Density Functional Theory (OF-DFT) is a theoretical approach to electronic structure that merges the strengths of local density and wavefunction-based methodologies. This theory is derived from traditional Density Functional Theory (DFT) by distributing the total energy into a linear combination of local power functionals, each dependent on the electron density and an additional parameter. These parameters, known as potentials, are determined by solving a constrained minimization problem. Unlike DFT, OF-DFT does not rely on a single-ion wavefunction, allowing it to effectively address the complexities of both molecular and solid-state systems. We present an implementation of this principle that uses a numerical formulation of the Schrödinger equation in Lagrangian form. The theory has been validated across various molecules and solids, demonstrating strong performance in numerous test cases. Additionally, we explore a case study of graphene on Au (111), revealing that interaction-mediated physisorption and chemisorption significantly influence the structural configurations observed.

original_text: J 0903+0357 is a nearby L dwarf observed by the Gaia satellite in the preliminary data release. It has a radial velocity and two new optical spectra, one from GTC and one from LBT. J 0903+0357 is one of the most distant and faintest L dwarfs yet observed. J 0903+0357 s radial velocity is 22.2 km/s, indicating it is a low-mass member of the local solar neighborhood. The spectra are consistent with L dwarf characteristics, but the JHK colors are unusual for L dwarfs, especially its red color. This color cannot be explained by the late-M spectral classification, so it may be a binary or a very low surface gravity object. If it is a binary, it would be the most distant and most tightly bound system of any L dwarf. Alternatively, a late-L companion to a mid-M dwarf could explain the red color. It will be important to observe J 0903+0357 over multiple epochs to determine which of these scenarios is correct.

rewrite_text: J 0903 + 0357 is a nearby L dwarf identified in the preliminary image release by the Gaia satellite. It exhibits a radial velocity of 22.2 km/s, indicating it is a lightweight member of the local solar neighborhood, along with two new optical spectra obtained from GTC and LBT. Notably, J 0903 + 0357 ranks among the most distant and faintest L dwarfs observed to date. While the spectra align with typical L dwarf characteristics, its JHK colors are unusual, especially its pronounced red hue. This color does not align with early-M spectral classifications, suggesting the possibility that it could be a binary system or a very low-mass object. If it is indeed a binary, it would represent the most distant and tightly bound system among known L dwarfs. Alternatively, a late-L companion to a mid-M dwarf could account for the observed red color. Ongoing observations of J 0903 + 0357 over multiple epochs will be essential to determine which of these possibilities is correct.

original_text: Twenty three globular clusters (GCs) in the inner region of the Milky Way are called the bulge globular clusters. These clusters are very old and have low metallicities. Consequently they have red horizontal branches (RHBs). Terzan 5, Liller 1, UKS 1 and Terzan 4 are very luminous and massive, and are known to have extended cores. HST observations in the F110W and F160W bands were used to obtain their relative proper motions and consequently their 3D space positions. These four clusters are on average 31.2 kpc from the Galactic center. Terzan 5 is at a distance of 25.3 kpc from the Galactic center, which is closer than the Galactic center. This cluster is the closest to the center of the Milky Way among the known globular clusters. The other clusters are at distances of 32.4 kpc (Liller 1), 33.7 kpc (UKS 1) and 38.1 kpc (Terzan 4). The spatial distribution of the bulge globular clusters has important consequences for the formation and evolution of the Galaxy. Terzan 5 is a possible globular cluster progenitor that may have been disrupted by the central supermassive black hole. The other clusters are likely to have formed during the early stages of the Galaxy s formation.

rewrite_text: The inner region of the Milky Way contains twenty-three globular clusters known as bulge globular clusters. These clusters are extremely old and exhibit low metallicity, resulting in red horizontal branches (RHBs). Among them, Terzan 5, Liller 1, UKS 1, and Terzan 4 stand out as particularly luminous and massive, featuring extended cores. Observations from the Hubble Space Telescope in the F110W and F160W bands were utilized to determine their relative proper motions and, subsequently, their three-dimensional positions in space. All four clusters are located at an approximate distance of 31.2 kpc from the Galactic center. Terzan 5, at a distance of 25.3 kpc, is the closest known globular cluster to the Milky Way's center. In contrast, Liller 1 lies at 32.4 kpc, UKS 1 at 33.7 kpc, and Terzan 4 at 38.1 kpc from the Galactic center. The spatial arrangement of these bulge globular clusters provides valuable insights into the Galaxy's formation and evolution. Notably, Terzan 5 is considered a potential progenitor of a globular cluster that may have been disrupted by the central supermassive black hole, while the other clusters likely formed during the Galaxy's nascent stages.

original_text: The characterization of instrumental phase stability is necessary for several applications in astronomy such as the detection of meteors, the study of the atmosphere or for the detection of artificial satellites. In the field of radio astronomy, phase stability is necessary to achieve the coherence needed to conduct precision astronomical observations. The coherence is obtained by referencing the signal to an external source whose stability is known with great precision (a hydrogen maser for instance). The stability of the astronomical instrument itself is the amount of jitters that does not degrade the coherence of the signal. To characterize the phase stability of the IRAM 30-meter telescope, we implemented a phase referenced signal at 10.5 cm in the form of a dual channel Bracewell discriminator. By doing this, we could measure the phase stability between two channels every 20 minutes with a 1.1 millas RMS. We have also shown how to compute the equivalent closed loop transfer function of the system. This is relevant for the control community because this kind of measurements are often used as a probe for the stability of an Airbus A300 airplane or a satellite. This stability is very important for their reliability.

rewrite_text: Characterizing instrumental phase stability is essential for various scientific applications, including monitoring meteors, clouds, and artificial satellites. In radio astronomy, phase stability is crucial for achieving the coherence needed for precise astronomical measurements. This coherence is obtained by referencing the signal to an external source with well-established stability, such as a hydrogen maser. The stability of the astronomical instrument itself refers to the level of jitter that does not compromise the coherence of the signal. To assess the phase stability of the IRAM 30-meter telescope, we implemented a phase-referenced signal at 10.5 centimeters using a twin-channel Bracewell discriminator. This setup allowed us to evaluate the phase stability between two signals every 20 minutes, achieving an RMS jitter of 1.1 millas. Additionally, we demonstrated how to calculate the equivalent closed-loop transfer function of the device. This information is particularly relevant for the control community, as such measurements are frequently used to probe the stability of aircraft, like the Airbus A300, or spacecraft, underscoring the importance of this integrity for their reliability.

original_text: Pappus s theorem in plane geometry states that three lines in the plane intersecting in a triad of points, there exists a fourth line not in the plane, containing one of the triad of points. There have been many proofs of this theorem since it was first stated in the 2nd century AD. In this short note we present a simple and beautiful proof of Pappus s theorem that has some interesting geometric and algorithmic applications. Our approach is to discretize Pappus s configuration of lines in the plane and solve an arrangement problem on a gridded plane. The theorem follows as a special case of the theorem for this problem. We also present an alternate, but more complex and less direct, proof of Pappus s theorem, which may be of independent interest. esk A simple and beautiful proof of Pappus s theorem We present a simple and beautiful proof of Pappus s theorem that has some interesting geometric and algorithmic applications. rewrite_text: Pappus's theorem in plane geometry asserts that if three lines in a plane intersect at three distinct points, there exists a fourth line, not in the plane, that passes through one of these intersection points. Since its introduction in the 2nd millennium AD, many proofs of this theorem have emerged. In this brief note, we present a simple and elegant proof of Pappus's theorem that highlights some intriguing geometric and algorithmic applications. Our approach involves discretizing the arrangement of lines in the plane and addressing a spatial organization problem on a grid. The theorem is derived as a specific case of a broader theorem related to this problem. Additionally, we provide an alternative proof of Pappus's theorem that, while more complex and informal, may still hold independent significance.

original_text: Massive stars are formed in clusters. Their massive radiative and mechanical energies profoundly influence their environment. Despite their prevalence and crucial impact, the massive star formation process, particularly in its earliest phases, is difficult to observe due to the high spatial resolution and sensitivity needed. The water masers arise only in actively forming massive stars and gas reservoir, and so provide an excellent probe of this earliest phase. Using new Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations, we detect 23 new radio water masers associated with the high-mass star formation in the Nuclear Disk of the Milky Way. The distribution, velocities, and dispersion of the water masers are consistent with them tracing an inclined rotating disk. The dynamical mass of the disk is estimated to be (3.6±0.7)×10^5 M⊙, comparable to the previous upper limit of the Nuclear Disk. This, along with the coincident far-infrared and γ-ray emissions, suggests the current high-mass star formation in the Nuclear Disk is in an early stage with substantial amounts of gas and dust.

rewrite_text: Massive stars form in clusters, and their immense radiative and physical energies significantly influence their surroundings. Although these stars are common and play a vital role in the universe, observing the massive transitions in galaxy formation, especially during its early stages, is challenging due to the high levels of visual clarity and sensitivity required. Water masers, which occur exclusively in regions of active massive star formation and gas accumulation, serve as excellent indicators of this nascent phase. Through new Very Long Baseline Interferometry (VLBI) observations, we have identified 23 newly discovered radio water masers linked to high-mass star formation in the Nuclear Disk of the Milky Way. The distribution, velocities, and dispersion of these water masers suggest they are tracing an inclined rotating disk. The estimated dynamical mass of this disk is (3.6 ± 0.7) × 10^5 [UNK], which is consistent with the previous upper limit measured for the Nuclear Disk. This observation, combined with corresponding far-infrared and gamma-ray emissions, indicates that the current high-mass star formation in the Nuclear Disk is still in its early stages and contains significant amounts of gas and dust.

original_text: In this paper, we construct supersymmetric solitons of QKdV equation (also known as mKdV equation in short) in arbitrary genus Riemann surfaces. The spectral problem for QKdV equation is first reduced to the spectral problem for the mKdV equation by using the Riemann-Hilbert problem. Then we use modified Riemann-Hilbert problem to construct the multi-solitons of QKdV equation. The corresponding spectral data for this solitons includes some genus 0 spectral data and some genus N with N solitons spectral data. We name these solitons of arbitrary genus. It is shown that the multi-solitons of arbitrary genus constructed here correspond to some Hamiltonian motion on the Jacobi varieties of genus N non-hyperelliptic curves. The spectral problem for QKdV equation is first reduced to the spectral problem for the mKdV equation by using the Riemann-Hilbert problem. Then we use modified Riemann-Hilbert problem to construct the multi-solitons of QKdV equation. The corresponding spectral data for this solitons includes some genus 0 spectral data and some genus N with N solitons spectral data. We name these solitons of arbitrary genus. It is shown that the multi-solitons of arbitrary genus constructed here correspond to some Hamiltonian motion on the Jacobi varieties of genus N non-hyperelliptic curves. This article has been reviewed by Qing Yang of Peking University. rewrite_text: In this paper, we develop supersymmetric solitons of the QKdV function (commonly referred to as the mKdV formula) on Riemann surfaces of arbitrary genus. Initially, the spectral problem for the QKdV equation is transformed into the spectral problem for the mKdV equation using the Riemann-Hilbert problem. We then employ a modified Riemann-Hilbert problem to construct multi-solitons of the QKdV equation. The spectral information associated with these solitons includes data from genus 0 as well as spectral information for genus N that corresponds to N solitons. We refer to these as solitons of arbitrary genus. It is shown that the multi-solitons of arbitrary genus that we have constructed correlate with Hamiltonian dynamics on the Jacobi varieties of non-hyperelliptic curves of genus N. This section has been discussed by Qing Yang from Peking University. Abstract: In this paper, we create supersymmetric solitons of the QKdV function (briefly mKdV) on Riemann surfaces of arbitrary genus. We initially reduce the spectral problem for the QKdV function to that of the mKdV function via the Riemann-Hilbert problem. Subsequently, we apply a modified Riemann-Hilbert approach to generate the multi-solitons of the QKdV function. The resultant spectral information encompasses contributions from genus 0 and genus N, where these N solitons' spectral details are included. We designate these as solitons of arbitrary genus. Our findings indicate that the constructed multi-solitons of arbitrary genus are linked to Hamiltonian movements within the Jacobi varieties of non-hyperelliptic curves of genus N. This section is protected by Ten.

original_text: Dirichlet sigma models and mean curvature flow are widely studied in geometry and physics, with important applications in surface and interface motion, phase transitions, and material science. In this paper we show how to derive sigma models from the more fundamental theories of quantum gravity. We use the background independent quantization of 2+1 gravity, Vasiliev theory, to derive sigma models for interfaces in (2+1)-dimensional quantum gravity. This provides a geometrical interpretation of the (2+1)-dimensional quantum gravity dynamical variables as an (2+1)-dimensional analogue of the relativistic membrane. We show that the mean curvature flow is the $0$-th order perturbative expansion of the gradient flow for the quantum gravity action, and describe the higher order corrections in the flow. This theory provides a geometrical interpretation of higher order corrections to the mean curvature flow. By analogy with the example of the relativistic membrane, this may give us new insights into the behavior of these flows in general, and the behavior of solutions near singularities in particular. The theory also has implications for the potential experimental tests of this theory: In various regimes of physical interest, the gravitational interaction between probes is weak and may be described by a sigma model with a world-sheet metric independent of the target space geometry. This means that many proposed experiments to test two-dimensional quantum gravity cannot distinguish this theory from sigma models based on otherworldly targets. However, there are regimes where the theory deviates from a sigma model, such as at strong coupling or near a critical point, and in these cases gravity may give a detectable signal. This work was performed within the program of theoretical physics of fundamental interactions of the Russian Academy of Sciences, and was supported in part by the Russian Found for Fundamental Research, Grant No. 16-32-00137. The abstract has been approved by the arXiv.org moderators and may be found here: https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.07497

rewrite_text: Dirichlet sigma models and mean curvature flow are well-established concepts in geometry and mechanics, playing crucial roles in surface dynamics, interface movement, phase transitions, and materials science. In this paper, we demonstrate how to derive sigma models from the more fundamental theories of quantum gravity. Specifically, we utilize the background-independent quantization of 2+1 gravity, along with Vasiliev theory, to formulate sigma models for interfaces in 2+1-dimensional quantum gravity. This approach provides a geometric interpretation of the dynamical variables in 2+1-dimensional quantum gravity as an analogue of the relativistic membrane. We reveal that mean curvature flow represents the zeroth-order perturbative expansion of the gradient flow associated with the quantum gravitational action, and we characterize the higher-order corrections to this flow. This theoretical framework offers a geometric interpretation of these higher-order corrections to mean curvature flow. When compared to the relativistic membrane, this could enhance our understanding of the dynamics of these flows in general, particularly concerning the behavior of solutions near singularities. Additionally, the theory has implications for potential experimental tests: in various relevant physical regimes, the gravitational interactions between probes are week enough that they can be accurately described by a sigma model with a world-sheet metric that is independent of the target space geometry. Consequently, many proposed experiments intended to assess two-dimensional quantum gravity may not effectively distinguish this theory from sigma systems linked to alternate target scenarios. Nevertheless, in certain regimes, such as when interactions are weak or near critical positions, deviations from the sigma description may occur, potentially yielding detectable signals from gravitational effects. This research was conducted as part of the theoretical physics program focused on fundamental interactions at the Russian Academy of Sciences and received partial support from the Russian Foundation for Fundamental Research, Grant No. 16-32-00137. The abstract has been approved by the moderators of arXiv and can be accessed at: https://arxiv.org/abs/1709.07497.

original_text: Clues, or cluesets, are used to guide the sampling process. A clueset contains a seed, a sampling range, and a sampling density function. Starting from the seed, the sampling range is divided into equal sized subsamples. The subsamples are scored according to the sampling density function, and the highest scoring subsample is chosen as the next sample. This process is repeated until the goal sample size is reached. Clues can be weighted according to their probability, so that biased samples can be generated. For example, if it is required to sample only Pathumthani people, Thailand, then Pathumthani is the seed, Thailand is the sampling range, and the probability of each Thai province being Pathumthani people is the sampling density function. This can be extended by creating a bank of clues, which can be selected from and reused for various sampling tasks. The bank can contain several hundred thousand clues and still fit in memory.

rewrite_text: Clues, or cluesets, are utilized to aid the sampling method. A clueset consists of a seed, a sampling range, and a sampling density function. Starting from the seed, the sampling range is divided into equal-sized subsamples. These subsamples are evaluated based on the sampling density function, and the top-ranked subsample is selected as the second sample. This procedure is repeated until the desired sample capacity is achieved. Clues can be assigned weights according to their likelihood, allowing for biased samples to be generated. For example, if the goal is to survey individuals from Pathumthani, Thailand, then Pathumthani serves as the seed, Thailand as the sampling range, and the probability of each Thai individual being from Pathumthani represents the sampling density function. This process can be further improved by creating a bank of clues that can be drawn upon and reused for various sampling tasks. This clue bank can contain hundreds of thousands of clues while still being manageable in memory.

original_text: Nonlinear oscillators based on semiconductor microcavities provide an excellent testbed for studying chaos, bifurcations, and non-linear effects1-3. An external periodic force, which can be applied either optically or electrically, can induce complicated and interesting behaviors4-7. In this Letter, we report a dynamics-controlled truncation scheme to find high-dimensional chaotic attractors in the semiconductor laser with a saturable absorber. By introducing a dynamics-dependent truncation procedure, long transient chaotic orbits are truncated by chaotic solutions of low-dimensional truncation systems. With this truncation scheme, we are able to observe novel dynamical behaviors in semiconductor laser with a saturable absorber, such as intermittency and bifurcations from torus to strange attractor. Our method can also be applied to any high-dimensional nonlinear system. We study the semiconductor laser with saturable absorber and external periodic force (SA+EFP). The laser dynamics can be described by the following equations7: +j0=σ(I+Iref)−(1−σ)I−j(γ+β|A|2)|A|^2+η(t);  1  where A is the complex field, and Iref, γ, β, σ, and η(t) are the reference current, gain loss, feedback gain, feedback loss, and time dependent perturbation, respectively. |A| is the magnitude of |A| and is proportional to the intensity of the optical field. By setting the external pump at the desired frequency, the laser dynamics can be reduced to a one dimensional map (1DMA), which is composed of two terms. The first term describes the phase dynamics, while the second term describes the intensity dynamics. In our simulation, we choose the parameters γ = 2 and β = 4, and the saturable loss coefficient σ = 0.8. By setting the modulation of external periodic force to be a limit-cycle oscillation, a chaotic attractor in 1DMA can be obtained. If the dynamics of the full model is truncated at a particular dimension, it is possible to observe long transient chaotic orbits in 1DMA. In addition, we can still observe the existence of limit-cycle oscillation in the truncated system. However, the truncation dimension controls the transient time of the chaotic orbit. If the truncation dimension is high, the transient chaotic orbit is long. If the transient chaotic orbit is long, we are able to observe more interesting dynamical behaviors. For example, if the transient chaotic orbit is long enough, it is possible to observe intermittency and bifurcations from torus to strange attractor. In contrast, if the transient chaotic orbit is too short, the dynamical behavior of the laser can not be observed.

rewrite_text: Nonlinear oscillators based on semiconductor microcavities serve as an excellent platform for investigating chaos, bifurcations, and non-discrete effects. By applying an external periodic force—either optically or electrically—complex and intriguing behaviors can be induced. In this Letter, we present an updated dynamics-controlled truncation scheme aimed at identifying high-dimensional chaotic attractors in semiconductor lasers equipped with saturable absorbers. By implementing a dynamics-dependent truncation approach, we can truncate lengthy transient turbulent orbits using turbulent solutions derived from low-dimensional truncation schemes. This technique allows us to uncover new dynamical interactions in semiconductor lasers with saturable absorbers, including intermittency and bifurcations transitioning from toroidal to odd attractors. Our methodology is applicable to any large-dimensional nonlinear system. We specifically focus on the semiconductor laser with a saturable absorber and an external periodic force (SA + EFP). The dynamics of the laser are described by the following equations: + j0 = σ (I + Iref) - (1-σ) I - j(γ + β |A|²)|A|² + η(t), where A represents the complex field, and Iref, γ, β, σ, and η(t) correspond to the reference current, gain loss, feedback gain, feedback loss, and time-dependent perturbation, respectively. The magnitude of |A| correlates with the frequency of the optical field. By setting the external pump at the desired wavelength, the laser dynamics can be simplified to a one-dimensional map (1DMA), consisting of two components: the phase dynamics and the intensity behavior. In our model, we select β = 2, β = 4, and the saturable failure coefficient σ = 0.8. By configuring the external periodic force modulation as a limit-cycle oscillation, we can generate a chaotic attractor within the 1DMA. When truncating the dynamics at a certain dimension, we can readily observe long transient turbulent orbits in the 1DMA. Moreover, limit-cycle oscillations are consistently present in the truncated system. The truncation dimension influences the duration of the chaotic orbit's transient state; a higher truncation dimension results in longer transient turbulent orbits, thereby enabling the observation of more fascinating dynamical interactions. For instance, when the transient turbulent orbit is sufficiently prolonged, intermittency and bifurcations can be clearly observed, transitioning from toroidal to odd attractors. However, if the transient turbulent orbit is excessively long, the dynamic behavior of the laser may become obscured.

original_text: Local purity distillation aims to remotely transmit unknown quantum states to a local server without disclosing any classical information to the server. Purity of the states to be transferred is required to be at least as high as the server’s capability to synthesize. In this paper, we propose and analyze a novel protocol Local Purity Distillation (LPD) with Bounded Classical Communication (BCC). LPD not only guarantees the remote state transfer with high fidelity, but also limits the server to a finite number of classical queries. In particular, for a 2-qubit state, LPD with BCC only requires the server to perform one query; for a 3-qubit state, the number of queries is two; and for an n-qubit state, the number of queries is O(n). In addition, we further analyze the secure quantum channel condition under LPD and present a tighter bound in the general case. Finally, we also give a real-world application example in digital signature to demonstrate the feasibility of the protocol.
watermark_text: Local purity distillation seeks to remotely send unknown quantum states to a local client without disclosing any classical knowledge to the server . Purity of the states to be transferred is required to be at least as great as the computer ’ s capability to synthesize .In this paper , we propose and analyze a new protocol Local Purity Distillation ( LPD ) with Bounded Classical Communication ( BCC ) . LPD not only provides the remote state connection with high fidelity , but also limits the client to a finite number of classical queries .In particular , for a 2 - qubit state , LPD with BCC only needs the client to conduct one query ; for a 3 - qubit state , the number of queries is two ; and for an n - qubit state , the number of queries is O ( n ) . In addition , we further analyze the secure quantum channel situation under LPD and present a tighter limit in the general case .Finally , we also get a real - time application instance in digital signature to test the feasibility of the method .
rewrite_text: Local purity distillation aims to transmit unknown quantum states to a local client while ensuring that no classical information is shared with the server. The purity of the states to be transmitted must meet or exceed the computer's synthesis capabilities. In this paper, we introduce and examine a novel protocol called Local Purity Distillation (LPD) with Bounded Classical Communication (BCC). LPD facilitates a high-fidelity remote state transfer while restricting the client to a limited number of classical queries. Specifically, for a 2-qubit state, the client requires only one query; for a 3-qubit state, two queries are necessary; and for an n-qubit state, the number of queries scales as O(n). Additionally, we analyze the LPD protocol in the context of secure quantum channels and establish a more stringent limit in general scenarios. Finally, we also present a real-time application case involving digital signatures to evaluate the practicality of the method.

original_text: The emission from high energy particles in gamma rays and very high energy (VHE, E>100 GeV) particles in particles in accelerators like the Large Hadron Collider is known to be strongly dependent on the physical conditions near the acceleration sites. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), a system of major atmospheric Cherenkov telescopes located in southern Arizona, has been observing a sample of active galaxies (called BL Lac objects) that are commonly thought to be located near the center of their hosts  gravitational wells. To date, these observations have shown that the spectrum of these objects does not harden, i.e., the slope of the energy spectrum (d log I/d log E) does not change as the flux (I) increases. New observations with VERITAS spanning 9 years of data (from 2008 to 2017) suggest that the spectrum may harden at fluxes exceeding 10(-11) cm(-2) s(-1) GeV. While this finding seems to contradict what is known about gamma-ray emission from other sources, there are several aspects of the sample and analysis that may account for this. Further analysis of the full data set is needed to confirm this surprising finding.

rewrite_text: The emission of high-energy ions in gamma radiation and very high-energy (VHE, E > 100 GeV) electrons in particle accelerators, such as the Large Hadron Collider, is significantly influenced by the physical conditions surrounding the acceleration sites. The Very Energetic Radiation Imaging Telescope Array System (VERITAS), a network of key atmospheric Cherenkov telescopes located in southern Arizona, has been observing a sample of active galaxies known as BL Lac objects, which are often found near the centers of their host galaxies' gravitational wells. To date, these observations have indicated that the spectrum of these objects does not exhibit hardening; in other words, the slope of the energy spectrum (d log I / d log E) remains unchanged as the flux (I) increases. However, new findings from VERITAS, based on 9 years of data (from 2008 to 2017), suggest that the spectrum may harden at flux levels exceeding 10^(-11) cm^(-2) s^(-1) GeV. While this result seems to contradict existing knowledge about gamma-ray radiation from other sources, certain aspects of the sample and the investigation could provide explanations. A thorough analysis of the entire data set is necessary to validate this unexpected finding.

original_text: Distributed network topologies are commonly established by some central authority according to geographic proximity, link availability, or other arbitrary constraints. In this work, we design a decentralized, localized approach to network topology formation, whereby each sensor node randomly and independently forms links to other sensor nodes. We present conditions under which this decentralized approach leads to substantially denser networks compared to existing centralized approaches based on similar assumptions. We also present two versions of the proposed protocol for partially and fully random networks. In partially random networks, some connectivity constraints, such as a minimum number of neighbors, are fulfilled; in fully random networks, all constraints are fulfilled. We evaluate our protocol through extensive simulations and illustrate its applicability to sensor networks in large venues such as a college campus.  We envision a wide range of applications for our approach. For example, it can be used to generate ad hoc networks for emergency services with the goal of expediting the delivery of emergency services communications, or for wireless sensor networks deployed in large venues such as a college campus, where the generated networks have the desired properties of high density and full randomness.
watermark_text: Distributed system topologies are often established by some central authority according to geographic proximity , link allocation , or other arbitrary limitations . In this research , we design a decentralized , localized approach to system topology structure , whereby each sensor node randomly and independently creates connections to other sensor nodes .We present terms under which this decentralized method results to substantially denser networks relative to existing centralized methods using on similar assumptions . We additionally offer two variants of the suggested protocol for partially and fully random networks .In partially random networks , some connectivity restrictions , such as a minimum amount of neighbors , are fulfilled ; in fully random networks , all constraints are fulfilled . We evaluate our protocol through elaborate simulations and illustrate its applicability to sensor networks in large areas such as a college campus .We envision a broad variety of applications for our approach . For instance , it can be used to create ad hoc networks for emergency services with the objective of expediting the supply of urgent personnel communications , or for wireless sensor networks deployed in large sites such as a college campus , where the produced channels have the desired properties of high density and complete randomness .
rewrite_text: Distributed system topologies are typically configured by a central authority based on factors such as geographic proximity, link distribution, or other specific criteria. In this research, we propose a decentralized and localized approach to structuring system topologies, where each sensor node autonomously and randomly connects to other sensor nodes. We introduce the conditions under which this decentralized strategy yields significantly denser networks compared to traditional centralized methods based on similar assumptions. Additionally, we present two versions of our proposed protocol tailored for partially and fully random networks. In partially random networks, certain connectivity constraints, such as a minimum number of neighbors, are met, whereas in fully random networks, all constraints are satisfied. We assess our protocol through comprehensive simulations and demonstrate its relevance for sensor networks across large areas, such as college campuses. We foresee a wide range of applications for our method, including the formation of ad hoc networks for emergency services aimed at enhancing urgent personnel communications, as well as for wireless sensor networks in extensive locations, where the resulting connections exhibit high density and complete randomness.

original_text: The complexity of model checking higher-order logic has been a long-standing open problem. Since the 1980s, model checking has been reduced to decision problems for several fragments of higher-order logic. However, in the worst case, checking whether a given formula is satisfied by all fixpoints of a fixpoint logic formula requires solving a Picard iteration, an optimal fixpoint algorithm, for every projection of the logic formula. Thus, even when the logic formula is over a small set of variables, model checking Higher-Order Fixpoint Logic (HOF logic) is np-hard. We study HOF logic in the parameterized complexity framework, where the complexity of a problem is bound by a function of the size of the formula. We give two parameterizations: tree decomposition, and block decomposition. We show that model checking HOF logic with respect to tree decompositions is FPT, and we prove that model checking HOF logic with respect to block decompositions is not FPT. Our parameterizations leave plenty of room for further parameterizations. We also give a 3d-Printable structure, a width-bounded syntactic abstraction, that preserves FPT parameterized complexity.
watermark_text: The complexity of model checking upper - order logic has been a long - standing open challenge . Since the 1980s , model checking has been reduced to decision difficulties for numerous pieces of greater - order logic .However , in the worst case , searching whether a given formula is fulfilled by all fixpoints of a fixpoint reasoning formula involves solving a Picard iteration , an appropriate fixpoint algorithm , for every projection of the logic formula . Thus , even when the logic formula is over a small set of variables , model searching Higher - Order Fixpoint Logic ( HOF reasoning ) is np - hard .We explore HOF reasoning in the parameterized complexity formulation , where the complexity of a problem is bound by a function of the size of the formula . We get two parameterizations : tree transformation , and block decomposition .We see that model checking HOF reasoning with regard to tree decompositions is FPT , and we prove that model checking HOF reasoning with regard to block decompositions is not FPT . Our parameterizations leave lot of room for further parameterizations .We also get a 3d - Printable form , a width - bounded syntactic abstraction , that preserves FPT parameterized complexity .
rewrite_text: The complexity of model checking higher-order logic has been a persistent challenge. Since the 1980s, various decision problems within higher-order logic have been tackled through model checking. However, in the worst-case scenario, determining whether a specific formula is satisfied by all fixed points of a fixed-point reasoning formula requires executing a Picard iteration—an appropriate fixed-point algorithm—for each projection of the logical formula. Consequently, even with a limited set of variables, model checking for Higher-Order Fixed-Point Logic (HOF reasoning) is NP-hard. In this study, we examine HOF reasoning within the framework of parameterized complexity, where problem complexity is determined by a function of the formula's size. We investigate two parameterizations: tree transformation and block decomposition. Our findings indicate that model checking HOF reasoning concerning tree decompositions is fixed-parameter tractable (FPT), whereas model checking in relation to block decompositions is proven to be non-FPT. Additionally, our parameterizations suggest potential for further expansions. We also present a 3D-printable representation— a width-bounded syntactic abstraction—that retains FPT parameterized complexity.

original_text: Aiming at reducing the metallicity in a ferromagnetic material, we have fabricated a bilayer film with a thin layer of NiMnSb sandwiched between two thin layers of NiMnSb with a gradient of NiMnSb thickness. While the outer two layers have a constant composition of Ni50Mn50Sb20, the inner layer has a reduced Ni content of Ni40Mn50Sb20. As a result, the whole film becomes Ni40Mn30Sb20, with the Mn content increasing gradually from the inner to the outer layer, thus achieving a gradient of metallicity across the film. Experiments and first-principles calculations show that this gradient in the Mn content induces a gradient in the Ni3+ and Mn3+ concentrations, giving rise to a nearly full metallicity for the film. Because of the great potential of gradient metallicity for novel spintronic applications, this work may attract broad attention.
watermark_text: Aiming at lowering the metallicity in a ferromagnetic material , we have synthesized a bilayer film with a thin layer of NiMnSb sandwiched between two thin layers of NiMnSb with a gradient of NiMnSb thickness . While the inner two sheets have a constant structure of Ni50Mn50Sb20 , the inner layer has a reduced Ni content of Ni40Mn50Sb20 .As a result , the whole film becomes Ni40Mn30Sb20 , with the Mn content rising gradually from the inner to the exterior layer , thus producing a gradient of metallicity across the film . Experiments and first - principles measurements show that this gradient in the Mn content induces a gradient in the Ni3 + and Mn3 + concentrations , giving rise to a nearly full metallicity for the film .Because of the great potential of gradient metallicity for alternative spintronic use , this research could attract wide focus .
rewrite_text: In an effort to reduce the metallicity of a ferromagnetic material, we have developed a bilayer film consisting of a thin layer of NiMnSb positioned between two additional layers of NiMnSb, each with a varying thickness gradient. While the two outer layers maintain a consistent composition of Ni50Mn50Sb20, the inner layer features a decreased nickel content of Ni40Mn50Sb20. Consequently, the overall composition of the film results in Ni40Mn30Sb20, with manganese content increasing from the inner layer to the outermost layer, thereby creating a gradient of metallicity throughout the film. Experimental results and first-principles calculations indicate that this variation in manganese content leads to corresponding changes in the concentrations of Ni3+ and Mn3+, which ultimately results in a near-complete metallicity for the film. Given the significant potential of gradient metallicity for next-generation spintronic applications, this research is likely to garner considerable attention.

original_text: ANALYSIS OF SINGLE SPECTRA IN THE QUIET SUN SPECTRA FROM HMI AND MDI A single spectrum from the magnetic diagnostics on board SOHO and NASA s Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SUN / HDต Backasch et al. (1995): Two photospheric lines with opposite magnetic polarity are clearly visible in the intensity profiles. A possible explanation is the Zeeman effect. The result is in disagreement with the notion that the quiet Sun has no magnetic field. The signal to noise ratio in the quiet Sun, obtained with current technologies, is not sufficient to detect the weak fields of a few Gauss. The weakest fields in the solar atmosphere are observed in the photospheric layers, where the gas pressure and temperature are high. In particular, two photospheric lines with opposite magnetic polarity are clearly visible in the intensity profiles. A possible explanation is the Zeeman effect. The result is in disagreement with the notion that the quiet Sun has no magnetic field. The quiet Sun has a magnetic field of several hundred Gauss, although it is much weaker than the fields of active regions.

rewrite_text:
ANALYSIS OF SINGLE SPECTRA IN QUIET SUN SPECTRA FROM HMI AND MDI

Observations from the magnetic diagnostics aboard SOHO and NASA's Solar and Heliospheric Observatory (SUN) reveal distinct features in the intensity profiles of two photospheric lines exhibiting opposite magnetic polarities. This phenomenon can potentially be attributed to the Zeeman effect. These findings challenge the traditional view that the quiet Sun is devoid of magnetic forces. Current technology's signal-to-noise ratio in the quiet Sun is inadequate to detect the weak magnetic fields, which are typically around a few Gauss. The weakest magnetic fields in the solar atmosphere are found in photospheric structures, where gas pressure and temperature are elevated. It is important to note that while the quiet Sun possesses magnetic forces on the order of several hundred Gauss, these are much weaker compared to the fields present in active solar regions.

rewrite_text: In this paper, we present the two-loop differential beta function within the reduced-subtraction scheme for non-abelian gauge theories, specifically in the context of asymptotic freedom. The results are articulated in terms of the so-called evolved constant of the theory, which is defined as the solution to a specific differential equation. We discuss the structure of our findings and relate them to previous studies, including those referenced in the works of G. Burgio et al. (JHEP 11, 025, 2016), L.V. Atroshchenko et al. (Theor. Math. Phys. 185, 1762, 2015), N.V. Prokushkin and M.A. Vasiliev (Fortsch. Phys. 53, 741, 2005), and several others.

original_text: The UKIRT Infrared Deep Sky Survey (UKIDSS; Lucas et al. 2008) uses the United Kingdom Infrared Telescope (UKIRT) to survey the whole sky visible from Mauna Kea in Hawaii, in five optical bands and two infrared bands. In April 2010, UKIDSS completed its Early Data Release (EDR), including images of some areas that had not been observed by the UKIRT Wide Field Survey (uwfS; Collins et al. 2004). In this paper we present a new method of searching for distant galaxies by using these new UKIDSS EDR images of the Galactic Plane. We use the UKIDSS Galactic Plane Survey (GPLS; Hambly et al. 2008) to select two stellar populations, A and B, with different colours and ages. We then apply a colour-colour diagram, constructed using these two stellar populations and star-forming galaxies with known redshifts, to find regions in colour space where the distant galaxies can be found. We apply this technique to two separate areas of the sky, labelled L7 and L11, and find a total of 66 galaxies at redshifts greater than z = 1.5, with a mean distance of 92.2 ± 5.4 million light-years. We conclude that this new technique is a potentially useful method of selecting distant galaxies, and discuss the implications of this result for studies of the epoch of reionisation.  — RMCGP Team

We use the UKIDSS Galactic Plane Survey ( GPLS ; Hambly et al .2008 ) to select two stellar regions , A and B , with varying colours and periods . rewrite_text: The UKIRT Infrared Deep Sky Survey (UKIDSS; Lucas et al. 2008) employs the United Kingdom Infrared Telescope (UKIRT) to perform a comprehensive survey of the entire sky visible from Mauna Kea in Hawaii, utilizing five optical bands and two infrared bands. In April 2010, UKIDSS completed its Early Data Release (EDR), which included images of certain areas that had not been previously explored by the UKIRT Wide Field Survey (uwfS; Collins et al. 2004). In this paper, we introduce an innovative approach to identifying distant galaxies by analyzing the new UKIDSS EDR images of the Galactic Plane. We leverage the UKIDSS Galactic Plane Survey (GPLS; Hambly et al. 2008) to select two stellar regions, designated A and B, which exhibit diverse colors and periods. Subsequently, we create a color-color diagram using these two stellar populations along with galaxy-forming stars that have known redshifts, allowing us to pinpoint areas in color space where distant galaxies may be located. We apply this methodology to two distinct regions of the sky, labeled L7 and L11, resulting in the discovery of a total of 66 galaxies with redshifts exceeding z = 1.5, and an average distance of 92.2 ± 5.4 million light-years. This new technique presents a promising avenue for identifying distant galaxies, and we discuss its implications for research related to the epoch of reionization.— RMCGP Team

original_text: We present the discovery of 11 new T dwarfs in theTwo Micron All-Sky Survey (2MASS). We describe the process of matching 2MASS PSC point sources to WISE full-frame data, and present the resulting list of 22 new T dwarf counterparts. New T dwarfs found include the 23rd and 24th nearest star to the Earth, Teegarden s Star and Doornos  Star, respectively, and the closest known T dwarf binary, 2MASS J0746425+2000315. We present spectral types and photometry for all 22 newly discovered T dwarfs, and compare the spectral types and colors of these objects to those of previously known T dwarfs. Our spectral type determination for 2MASS J0746425+2000315 demonstrates the potential for discovering T dwarfs at greater distances. We estimate the distance to this T dwarf binary based on empirical models of spectral type versus absolute J-band magnitude, and find a likely distance range of 19–50 parsecs (66–167 light-years). We compare the observed mass-luminosity ratio of Teegarden s Star to current models of brown dwarf evolution and determine that this object is between the hydrogen-burning limit and the deuterium-burning limit. Future observations of Teegarden s Star will allow for further testing of these models, as well as the models  ability to predict the luminosities of ultracool dwarfs at intermediate ages. Finally, we examine the colors and luminosity function of the new T dwarfs, and compare the results to those of previous, similar studies. We observe a possible increase in the number of T dwarfs at fainter magnitudes (H- through L-type), and a possible deficiency of T dwarfs around the 2MASS absolute J-band magnitude of 7.5. However, due to the small number of T dwarfs in the sample and the large photometric errors at the fainter end of the luminosity function, these results should be interpreted with caution. We anticipate this work will contribute to existing spectroscopic and photometric dwarf catalogs and provide a useful sample for future studies of ultracool dwarfs.
watermark_text: We present the discovery of 11 new T dwarfs in theTwo Micron All - Sky Survey ( 2MASS ) . We explore the process of fitting 2MASS PSC point sources to WISE full - frame data , and reveal the resulting table of 22 fresh T dwarf neighbours .New T dwarfs discovered include the 23rd and 24th nearest star to the Earth , Teegarden s Star and Doornos Star , respectively , and the nearest known T dwarf binary , 2MASS J0746425 + 2000315 . We record spectral classes and photometry for all 22 newly discovered T dwarfs , and contrast the spectral classes and colors of these objects to those of previously known T dwarfs .Our spectral type determination for 2MASS J0746425 + 2000315 reveals the possibilities for finding T dwarfs at greater distances . We estimate the distance to this T dwarf binary based on empirical estimates of spectral type versus absolute J - band magnitude , and find a likely distance range of 19 – 50 parsecs ( 66 – 167 light - years ) .We relate the known mass - luminosity factor of Teegarden s Star to recent estimates of brown giant development and establish that this body is between the hydrogen - burning limit and the deuterium - burning limit . Future surveys of Teegarden s Star will provide for further study of these models , as well as the models able to predict the luminosities of ultracool dwarfs at intermediate ages .Finally , we investigate the colors and luminosity function of the new T dwarfs , and link the results to those of previous , related studies . We see a possible change in the proportion of T dwarfs at fainter magnitudes ( H - through L - class ) , and a possible deficiency of T dwarfs around the 2MASS absolute J - band magnitude of 7 . 5 .However , owing to the small number of T dwarfs in the sample and the huge photometric errors at the fainter middle of the luminosity function , these results should be interpreted with caution . We anticipate this research will add to existing spectroscopic and photometric dwarf catalogs and become a helpful sample for future research of ultracool dwarfs .
rewrite_text: We announce the identification of 11 new T dwarfs from the Two Micron All-Sky Survey (2MASS). Our investigation involves matching 2MASS Point Source Catalog (PSC) sources to WISE full-frame data, culminating in a table of 22 newly found T dwarf neighbors. Among the new discoveries are Teegarden's Star and Doornos Star, which are the 23rd and 24th closest stars to Earth, respectively, as well as the nearest known T dwarf binary, 2MASS J0746425 + 2000315. We compile spectral classifications and photometric data for all 22 newly identified T dwarfs and compare their spectral types and color characteristics to those of previously documented T dwarfs. Our analysis of the spectral type for 2MASS J0746425 + 2000315 suggests the potential for discovering T dwarfs at greater distances. We estimate this T dwarf binary's distance based on spectral type correlations with absolute J-band magnitude, resulting in a likely distance of 19 to 50 parsecs (66 to 167 light-years). We connect the known mass-luminosity relationship of Teegarden's Star to recent models of brown dwarf evolution, concluding that this star lies between the hydrogen-burning and deuterium-burning limits. Future observations of Teegarden's Star will enhance our understanding of these models and improve predictions of luminosities for ultracool dwarfs at intermediate ages. Additionally, we assess the colors and luminosity function of the new T dwarfs, relating our findings to prior studies. We note a possible shift in the ratio of T dwarfs at fainter magnitudes (H through L class) and a potential scarcity of T dwarfs around the 2MASS absolute J-band magnitude of 7.5. However, due to the limited sample size and significant photometric errors at these lower magnitudes, these findings should be interpreted cautiously. We expect this research will contribute to existing spectroscopic and photometric dwarf catalogs and serve as a valuable resource for future investigations into ultracool dwarfs.

original_text: On 12 February 2023, the potentially hazardous asteroid (144898) 2004 VD17 was identified by the Mount Lemmon Tenerife Observatory (MLAST) as it travelled around the Sun. This near-Earth object (NEO) is approximately 1-kilometre in diameter and has a minimum orbit intersection distance (MOID) of 0.0435 AU with Earth. If (144898) 2004 VD17 had an equivalent radius of 1 km when it passed through a distance of 0.0435 AU from Earth, it would have a probability of approximately 7.2 × 10−13 of making a close approach to the Earth and a 0.033% chance of impact. Here we report the results of a study carried out to better understand the physical properties of (144898) 2004 VD17 and determine its potential threat to Earth. To achieve this, observations of 2004 VD17 were acquired over two days using the Siding Springs Observatory, complemented by Earth-based radar observations from the Arecibo and Goldstone Observatories and high-resolution visual observations from the Uppsala Astronomical Observatory (UAO). These observations showed that (144898) 2004 VD17 is unlikely to impact Earth in 2023. Furthermore, it is likely to be a captured NEO, with a low probability of posing a significant threat to Earth in the future. Observations of (144898) 2004 VD17 indicate that it is most likely a captured asteroid whose orbit becomes unstable and cross that of Earth every few hundred years. The identification of 2004 VD17 only twelve months prior to its next near-Earth pass in 2023 suggests that it may not be stable on current orbit. This research highlights the utility of wide area surveys in the discovery of potentially hazardous objects. While the value of a rapid response search for near-Earth objects cannot be understated, high-precision astrometry with a wide field of view can find objects like (144898) 2004 VD17 well in advance of potential hazard determination. The use of additional data sources, such as radar data, in the discovery process can provide valuable information for characterizing potential hazards to improve the efficiency of response and mitigation efforts.

rewrite_text: On February 12, 2023, the potentially hazardous asteroid (144898) 2004 VD17 was detected by the Mount Lemmon Tenerife Observatory (MLAST) as it orbited the Sun. This near-Earth object (NEO) is roughly 1 kilometer in diameter and has a minimum orbit intersection distance (MOID) of 0.0435 AU from Earth. If (144898) 2004 VD17 maintained a similar size of 1 km while passing within 0.0435 AU of Earth, there would be approximately a 7.2 × 10^−13 chance of a close approach, translating to a 0.033% risk of impact. This report summarizes findings from a survey aimed at better understanding the physical characteristics of (144898) 2004 VD17 and assessing its potential threat to Earth. To gather data, observations of 2004 VD17 were made over two days using Siding Springs Observatory, in addition to radar measurements from the Arecibo and Goldstone Observatories and high-resolution imaging from the Uppsala Astronomical Observatory (UAO). The results indicated that (144898) 2004 VD17 is unlikely to impact Earth in 2023. Moreover, it is thought to be a captured NEO with a low likelihood of posing a significant threat in the future. Observations suggest that it is likely a captured asteroid whose orbit becomes unstable, crossing Earth's path every few centuries. The detection of 2004 VD17 only twelve weeks before its second near-Earth pass in 2023 implies that its current orbit may not be stable. This research highlights the importance of wide-area surveys in discovering potentially dangerous objects. While the benefits of rapid response searches for near-Earth objects are significant, high-speed astrometry with a wide field of view can identify asteroids like (144898) 2004 VD17 well in advance of any potential threats. Utilizing new data sources, such as radar observations, in the discovery process can provide crucial information for characterizing potential hazards and enhancing response and mitigation strategies.

original_text: In this work we consider a model for the early universe with a dynamical scalar field and a Chaplygin gas. The Chaplygin gas belongs to a family of models with a real scalar field with an effective negative pressure depending only on the density of the fluid. We assume that the radiation and the Chaplygin gas are two interacting fluids. We study the evolution of the corresponding scale factors and of the physical quantities describing the fluids. We show that this system of equations allows for a non-singular inflationary solution. Moreover, we compute the perturbations generated by this dynamics and we study their scale dependence. We show that the scalar spectrum of density perturbations is scale invariant for super-Hubble modes, in agreement with observations. Modeling the early universe as a dynamical system allows us to understand its evolution as the result of the interactions between its different components. This allows us to find non-singular inflationary solutions and to compute the scalar perturbations that they generate. Our results suggest that a model with a Chaplygin gas and radiation leads to a scale invariant spectrum of density perturbations, in agreement with observations. This allows us to find non-singular inflationary solutions and to compute the scalar perturbations that they generate. Our results suggest that a model with a Chaplygin gas and radiation leads to a scale invariant spectrum of density perturbations, in agreement with observations. rewrite_text:
In this study, we propose a framework for understanding the early universe featuring a dynamic scalar field alongside a Chaplygin gas. The Chaplygin gas is part of a class of models characterized by a real scalar field, exhibiting an effective negative pressure that relies solely on the liquid's density. We treat radiation and the Chaplygin gas as two interacting fluids and examine the evolution of the corresponding scale factors and the physical properties of these fluids. Our analysis reveals that this system of equations accommodates a non-singular inflationary solution. Furthermore, we calculate the perturbations arising from this dynamic and investigate their scale dependence. We find that the scalar spectrum of perturbations is scale invariant for super-Hubble modes, aligning with observational data. By modeling the early universe as a dynamic system, we can better understand its evolution as the result of various component interactions. This approach leads to the identification of non-singular inflationary solutions and allows us to compute the scalar perturbations they produce. Our findings suggest that a model incorporating both a Chaplygin gas and radiation results in a scale-invariant spectrum of perturbations, consistent with observations. 

Keywords: Early universe, Inflation, Scalar perturbations, Chaplygin gas.  
Date: April 11, 2014  
Author: André Godlowski  
E-mail: godlows@uis.pucp.ru  
URL: www.pucp.ru/godlows  

**Abstract:** This research provides insights into the behavior of the early universe and the initial conditions for inflation within a framework that includes both radiation and a Chaplygin gas. By approaching the early universe as a dynamic system, we gain a clearer understanding of its evolution, driven by the interplay of its constituent components. Our results indicate that this model yields non-singular inflationary solutions and allows for the calculation of scalar perturbations they generate, ultimately leading to a scale-invariant spectrum of perturbations that aligns with observational evidence.

original_text: In this paper, we consider the problem of blindly identifying a set of distributed antenna systems (DAS) from wireless channel measurements without requiring prior CSI or a database of DAS models. Unlike previous work, we characterize the measurement noise as aWN0 with unknown aweAte-1 covariance and propose a regularized non-convex cost function to solve for the DAS model. The aWN0 approximation is valid provided that the channel variations are slow compared to the inverse of the channel sample rate. Furthermore, we use the KKT conditions to derived a computationally efficient solution method. We validate the effectiveness of the proposed method through Monte-Carlo simulations. Our work differs from prior work on DAS identification in the following ways: (1) we characterize the measurement noise as aWN0 with uncertain covariance, and (2) we propose a regularized non-convex cost function to solve for the DAS model. The aWN0 approximation is valid provided that the channel variations are slow compared to the inverse of the channel sample rate. Furthermore, we use the KKT conditions to derived a computationally efficient solution method. We validate the effectiveness of the proposed method through Monte-Carlo simulations. References: 1. Zhou, Z. & Chen, Y. (2020). Blind Identification of Distributed Antenna Systems with Multiple Carrier Frequency Offsets. arXiv preprint arXiv:2006.11647. Blind Identification of Distributed Antenna Systems with Multiple Carrier Frequency Offsets  arXiv preprint arXiv:2006.11647.

rewrite_text: In this paper, we explore the challenge of distinguishing a distributed antenna system (DAS) based on wireless network measurements without relying on prior channel state information (CSI) or a repository of DAS models. Unlike previous studies, we define the monitoring noise as additive white Gaussian noise (AWGN) with an unknown but low-rank covariance structure and propose a regularized non-convex matrix to estimate the DAS model. The AWGN approximation holds true as long as the channel variations are slow relative to the inverse of the channel data rate. Additionally, we apply the Karush-Kuhn-Tucker (KKT) conditions to develop an efficient computational method for solving our proposed model. We demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach through Monte Carlo simulations. Our work diverges from prior research on DAS identification in two main aspects: (1) we model the monitoring noise as AWGN with an uncertain covariance, and (2) we introduce a regularized non-convex matrix for DAS model estimation. The AWGN approximation remains valid under the condition that channel variations are slow compared to the inverse of the channel data rate. We validate our proposed method's performance via Monte Carlo simulations. References: 1. Zhou, Z. & Chen, Y. (2020). Blind Identification of Distributed Antenna Systems with Multiple Carrier Frequency Offsets. arXiv preprint arXiv:2006.11647. This reference was sourced from a recent work in the field: Zhou, Zenghui; Chen, Yi (2020). Blind Identification of Distributed Antenna Systems with Multiple Carrier Frequency Offsets. arXiv preprint arXiv:2006.11647.

original_text: Recent observations suggest that the solar orbit around the center of the Galaxy may be spatially displaced with respect to the galactic disk. I present Bayesian estimates of the kinematic parameters of the solar motion based on a sample of highly probable stream stars with proper motions measured by the PPMX and SPM4 projects, as well as on a larger sample of probable stream stars from the GSC 2.2 and PPMX-PT projects. I find that the Sun’s moving with a 220 km/s velocity towards (galactic longitude, galactic latitude) = (305.9°, −2.4°) ± (3.6°, 2.4°) at a rate of −2.2 ± 0.2 km/s/kpc. Assuming a distance of the Sun from the galactic center of 8.5 kpc, this displacement implies a spatial half-thickness of the solar disk of 14 pc. The estimated Sun’s velocity is in agreement with previous results, while the spatial offset is less than previously believed.

Assuming a distance of the Sun from the galactic center of 8 . 5 kpc , this displacement implies a spatial half - thickness of the sun core of 14 pc .The estimated Sun ’ s speed is in agreement with previous findings , while the spatial offset is less than previously thought .
rewrite_text: Recent measurements indicate that the Sun's orbit around the center of the Galaxy may be spatially misaligned with respect to the galactic disk. I present Bayesian predictions for the kinematic values of the Sun's movement, based on a sample of likely stream stars with proper motions recorded by the PPMX and SPM4 projects, as well as a smaller set from the GSC 2.2 and PPMX-PT programs. My analysis shows that the Sun is traveling at a speed of 220 km/s towards the coordinates (galactic longitude, galactic latitude) = (305.9°, −2.4°) ± (3.6°, 2.4°), with a rate of −2.2 ± 0.2 km/s/kpc. Assuming the Sun is 8.5 kpc away from the galactic center, this displacement suggests a spatial half-thickness of the solar core of 14 pc. The estimated speed of the Sun aligns with previous studies, while the spatial offset is smaller than previously believed.

original_text: Galactic nebulae around core-collapse supernovae provide unique insights into the death throes of evolved stars. Observations of the spectrum of light emitted by the central supernova offer a unique means of uncovering the nature of the progenitor, with direct evidence for the presence of a stellar wind (from the progenitor s rapidly-evolving main sequence phase) or a core-collapse explosion. Despite several decades of studies, the nature of the most common core-collapse supernova progenitor is still disputed, with massive (~8-25M⊙) main-sequence stars having been implicated for some supernova subtypes. One particular supernova subtype, type Ia, has been used to significant cosmological depth and has an established connection to one (presently debated) progenitor class: white dwarfs accreting material from a companion. These descendants of ~8-25M⊙ stars, more commonly known as luminous blue variables (LBVs), have been proposed as a second, less well-understood class of core-collapse supernova progenitors. LBV outbursts (and the cessation of further evolution into a compact object) are generally interpreted as the result of either a sustained increase in mass-transfer from a binary companion, or as the onset of a thermonuclear explosion on the surface of the star. The region surrounding the supernova 1987A (Tycho) contains a contemporaneous LBV and a SN 1987A-like supernova ( 1988Z). This is a remarkable coincidence, and may hint at the viability of LBV outbursts as a mechanism for at least some supernova subtypes. The ages of the LBV and supernova are comparable, and recent data suggest that the progenitor of the supernova may have been a luminous blue variable - recent simulations suggest that a rare LBV eruption, ~200 years before the supernova, was likely the end point of rapid evolution towards a compact object. It has been speculated that the recent discovery of the  remnant  of a LBV explosion, ~30-60 years after the outburst, could provide compelling evidence for the viability of LBV explosions as a mechanism for supernovae. This manuscript examines the region surrounding SN 1987A (Tycho) in search of the remnant of the LBV eruption, using modern telescopes and data analysis techniques. We report the discovery of a faint, roughly spheroidal shell, which appears to be coincident with the observed positions of the LBV and the supernova 1987A. The shell is spatially and spectroscopically similar to similar objects observed in the vicinity of other supernova, and has a luminosity and expansion velocity consistent with it originating from a LBV explosion. The observed coincidence in space, age, and energetics provide circumstantial evidence that the LBV supernova explosion proposed by earlier simulations may in fact have occurred.

rewrite_text: Galactic nebulae surrounding core-collapse supernovae offer valuable insights into the final stages of evolved stars. Analyzing the light spectrum emitted by these supernovae is a powerful method for revealing the characteristics of their progenitors, providing direct evidence for the existence of a stellar wind from the progenitor's rapidly expanding main sequence phase, or indicating a core-collapse event. Despite many years of research, the nature of the most common progenitors for core-collapse supernovae remains contentious; some subtypes are linked to massive (~8-[UNK]) main sequence stars. Type Ia supernovae, in particular, have been extensively studied in cosmology and are associated with a debated progenitor type: brown dwarfs that accrete matter from a companion star. Additionally, luminous blue variables (LBVs), the progenitors of ~8-[UNK] stars, have been proposed as a second, less understood category of core-collapse supernova progenitors. LBV outbursts, which prevent further evolution into compact bodies, are generally thought to result from either significant mass transfer from a binary companion or the onset of a thermonuclear explosion on the star's surface. The region surrounding supernova 1987A (Tycho) contains an LBV and the supernova 1988Z, suggesting a noteworthy coincidence that may imply LBV outbursts can trigger some supernova subtypes. The ages of the LBV and the supernova are similar, and recent findings suggest that the progenitor of the supernova might have been an LBV—simulations indicate that a rare collapse of an LBV, occurring approximately 200 days before the supernova, likely marked the transition to a compact object. Moreover, a recent discovery of the remnant from an LBV explosion, about 30-60 days post-outburst, provides credible support for the idea that LBV explosions can lead to supernovae. This study focuses on the area surrounding SN 1987A (Tycho) to search for the remnants of the LBV eruption, utilizing modern telescopes and analytical methods. We report the detection of a dim, roughly spherical shell that appears to align with the locations of both the LBV and SN 1987A. This shell is spatially and spectroscopically related to similar objects found near other supernovae, exhibiting a luminosity and expansion velocity consistent with being the result of an LBV explosion. The observed spatial, temporal, and energetic similarities provide circumstantial evidence that supports the earlier simulations suggesting that an LBV supernova explosion likely occurred.

original_text: In this paper we provide Belyi-type theorems for the absolute Galois group of the rational numbers, written as a pro-finite group, acting on the components of the moduli space of surfaces. We use Galois cohomology with compact support in order to control the geometric part of the étale cohomology of the moduli spaces. By combining our results with previous work of Kevin Hutchinson, we deduce that the absolute Galois group acts faithfully on the components of the moduli space of surfaces. Our work has implications for the rigidity of the Absolute Galois group, namely that it is semisimple. In particular, we deduce that the topological fundamental group of the number field of defnition is trivial. We hope that our work will have further applications to the moduli problems of surfaces. For example, we use our results to deduce that the Hodge bundle on the moduli space of surfaces is nef and big, and so gives rise to a semi-stable family of curves. Our main tool is nonabelian cohomology, in particular the use of compact supports. We also use work of Kevin Hutchinson on the Frobenius morphism on the moduli space of curves. Finally, we also mention that our results confirm a prediction of Yau s generalized sndp conjecture. Keywords: Belyi theorem, Galois cohomology, moduli space of surfaces, Hodge bundle About this article: This article is from the user prof. lang van stoomburg on arXiv.org. Note: We have tried to provide an accurate description of the content of the article. However, we advise you to verify the claims made before using the information here for your own work. Kevin Hutchinson. Journal of the London Mathematical Society (2), 74(2):26-56, 2011. A Belyi-type theorem in higher dimension. Igor Pak, Volodymyr Muchnik, and Bruno Wenning. arXiv preprint arXiv:1503.06374, 2015. The full bibliographic citation for the second paper is: Igor Pak, Volodymyr Muchnik, and Bruno Wenning. rewrite_text:
In this paper, we present Belyi-type theorems related to the absolute Galois group of the rational integers, described as a pro-finite group, and its action on various components of the moduli space of surfaces. We employ Galois cohomology with compact support to enhance the geometric aspect of the étale cohomology of these moduli spaces. By integrating our results with earlier work by Kevin Hutchinson, we establish that the absolute Galois group acts faithfully on the components of the moduli space of surfaces, indicating implications for the rigidity of the Absolute Galois group, particularly that it is semisimple. Specifically, we conclude that the topological fundamental group of the defining number field is trivial. We anticipate that our research will contribute further to the study of moduli problems for surfaces. For example, we utilize our findings to demonstrate that the Hodge bundle on the moduli space of surfaces is nef and huge, thereby leading to a semi-stable family of curves. Our primary method revolves around nonabelian cohomology, especially through the use of smooth supports. We also apply insights from Kevin Hutchinson regarding the Frobenius morphism on the moduli space of curves. Lastly, we note that our results support a prediction made in Yau's generalized sndp theorem. 

**Keywords:** Belyi theorem, Galois cohomology, moduli space of surfaces, Hodge bundle
