rewrite_text:
We provide a detailed evaluation of the initial observational evidence for a candidate circumbinary planet (CBP) orbiting PP, based on an analysis of Swift/XRT data collected during a deep decay segment. The Swift/XRT monitored Swift J164449.3-311543 for a period of 170 days, from February 2015 to August 2016. The light curve can be roughly categorized into three phases: a deeper decay segment (SDS), a normal degradation segment (NDS), and a sharp decay segment (SDS). The SDS is interpreted as the early super-Eddington radiation resulting from a tidal disruption event (TDE) associated with the CBP. 

In our analysis of the SDS, we utilize both a simple one-zone reprocessing model and a more advanced multi-zone reprocessing model. Our findings indicate that several physical processes are necessary to account for the observed light curve behavior: (1) stellar debris absorbed power through internal shocks during the SDS; (2) the wind from the accretion ring provided cooling for the CBP; (3) the tidal disruption flare (TDF) from the CBP illuminated the planet; (4) interactions between dust and the CBP, as well as between dust and the disk, contributed to the early light influx; and (5) ongoing energy contribution from the primary supermassive black hole (SMBH).

Furthermore, we compare the anticipated reflection signature from the CBP with observational data to impose constraints on the distance between the CBP and the black hole (BH). Our comprehensive assessment of the SDS integrates both the one-zone and multi-zone reprocessing models to provide insights into these dynamics.

original_text: Recent observations of the center of our Galaxy, Sagittarius A* (Sgr A*), have revealed that it is encircled by an enormous, quasi-periodic radio emission cloud known as the Sgr A West radio lobe. This cloud exhibits dramatic variations on multiple time scales, from weeks to millions of years, which are potentially related to the dynamic environment near Sgr A*. Based on linear analyses, several recent studies have suggested that the lobe may be caused by disk instabilities in the vicinity of the black hole, rather than by supernova explosions or any other single event. Here, we present the results of three-dimensional general relativistic magnetohydrodynamical simulations of disk-generated turbulence and magnetic fields, which indicate that the dynamical environment around Sgr A* is likely a long-term stable and persistent phenomenon. In our model, the low-frequency radio variations are caused by the fluctuations in the mass inflow rate from the circumnuclear disk to the supermassive black hole, with a periodicity of tens of thousands of years. This result is consistent with several independent lines of observational and theoretical evidence, and may resolve the long-standing problem of the dynamical origin of the Sgr A West radio lobe.

This cloud exhibits significant fluctuations over a wide range of time scales, from weeks to millions of years, which may be linked to the active environment around Sgr A*. This outcome aligns with various observational and theoretical evidence and could resolve the longstanding debate regarding the dynamic origin of the Sgr A West broadcast lobe.

original_text: The purpose of this work is to characterize the conformational preferences of specific side chains in model polymer systems using experimental methodology and a combination of molecular mechanics and NMR calculations. Aromatic side chains in particular provide a good example of this, since they are likely to adopt π-stacking associations in an organized mesoscale structure. Such associations, formed via π-π stacking between ring systems, have been identified as critical for many physical properties of practical interest in polymer systems, including crystalline perfection, reactivity, and mechanical behavior. Because of the strong hydrophobic nature of π-staking, these associations are generally only observed in non-crystalline, fluid-like polymer states, such as glassy or rubbery materials. In this study, we provide experimental methodology for the measurement of side chain rotameric populations in model polymer systems, using 1H NMR spectroscopy and a combination of molecular mechanics and empirical potential calculations. The aromatic side chains 4-fluoronitrobenzene and 4-chloronitrobenzene are examined as a model system, and particular emphasis is given to the quantification of side chain rotameric isomers in crystalline and glassy states. In addition to characterizing the impact of side chain identity and conformation on macroscopic physical properties, these results provide useful reference data for the development and validation of more advanced physical modeling approaches for polymer systems.

Aromatic side rings are especially noteworthy, as they tend to engage in organized π-stacking interactions at a mesoscale level. These interactions, characterized by π-π stacking between ring structures, are essential for various fundamental physical properties of polymers, including crystalline perfection, reactivity, and overall physical characteristics. Beyond characterizing how side ring identification and conformation affect macroscopic physical properties, these findings also provide valuable reference data for the development and validation of advanced structural modeling techniques in polymer science.

original_text: In quantum field theories (QFTs), the local symmetry according to which particles have definite values of certain conserved quantum numbers, known as isotopic or conserved charge symmetries, restricts the form of local interactions. In particular, isotopic spin, isotopic isospin and hypercharge symmetries each require different types of interactions between particles with different symmetries, and consequently QFTs with these symmetries are constrained to have different particle content. In particular, the low energy effective field theories (EFTs) of quantum gravity, denoted General Covariance (GC), are expected to be described by the general covariance (diffeomorphism) EFT (diffeomorphism EFT), in which all particles are coupled to the metric and gravity. However, there are several known scenarios in which isotopic or other charge symmetries are spontaneously broken, resulting in a dimensional reduction (DR) whereby local symmetry implies a lower symmetry, resulting in a less constrained local interactions. Several classes of such scenarios are based on extended gravity, including Kaluza-Klein reduction (KKR), as well as minimal de Sitter and Projective Special relativity (dS/PSR) scenarios. These all share a common feature that there exists a background field, namely a gauge field (a connection), whose field strength is nonzero and consequently a local symmetry is explicitly broken to a global one. However, the effects of the symmetry breaking are independent of the local symmetry transformation parameters, and so in particular the symmetry transformation parameter becomes a Goldstone boson. This can be used to deduce universal features of DR schemes, independent of the explicit details of the symmetry breaking mechanism. For example, it is expected that all spontaneously broken isotopic or other charge symmetries will result in a reduced local symmetry, with the local symmetry transformation parameter corresponding to a Goldstone boson. In particular, for the minimal de Sitter and Projective Special relativity scenarios, there is an exact symmetry between the local de Sitter (dS) and global Poincaré symmetries, resulting in an exact Goldstone boson equivalence. Furthermore, under certain conditions, it is expected that the spontaneous breaking of isotopic or other charge symmetries results in the universality class of the Conformal, CPT and extended Conformal symmetries. These results imply universal features of DR schemes, independent of the explicit details of the symmetry breaking mechanism.

rewrite_text: In quantum field theories (QFTs), local symmetries dictate that particles possess definite values for certain conserved quantum numbers, commonly referred to as isotopic or conserved charge symmetries, which impose constraints on local interactions. Specifically, symmetries such as isotopic spin, isotopic isospin, and hypercharge lead to various types of particle couplings, resulting in different particle content in QFTs governed by these symmetries. Particularly, effective field theories (EFTs) for quantum gravity, indicated by General Covariance (GC), are anticipated to be governed by a diffeomorphism EFT, where all particles are coupled to the metric and gravity. However, there are known instances where isotopic or other charge symmetries undergo spontaneous breaking, leading to dimensional reduction (DR) where a local symmetry is manifested as a smaller symmetry, thereby allowing for less constrained local interactions. Many of these scenarios are associated with extended gravity frameworks, such as Kaluza-Klein reduction (KKR) and minimal de Sitter and Projective Special Relativity (dS/PSR) contexts. A common feature among these scenarios is the presence of a background gauge field (connection) with non-zero field intensity which explicitly breaks the local symmetry to a global one. Notably, the effects stemming from this symmetry breaking are independent of the local symmetry shift parameters, making the symmetry shift parameter a Goldstone boson. This insight allows for the derivation of fundamental characteristics of DR systems, irrespective of the specifics of the symmetry breaking process. For instance, it is expected that all spontaneously broken isotopic or other charge symmetries will lead to a diminished local symmetry, with the local symmetry shift parameter transitioning into a Goldstone boson. In the cases of reduced de Sitter and Projective Special Relativity, a precise symmetry exists between local de Sitter (dS) and global Poincaré symmetries, yielding similar Goldstone boson behavior. Additionally, under specific conditions, spontaneous breaking of isotopic or other charge symmetries is projected to result in universal traits of Conformal, CPT, and extended Conformal symmetries. These findings suggest inherent characteristics of DR systems, independent from the exact mechanisms involved in the symmetry breaking process.

original_text: In this work, we present a spectroscopic and photometric survey of Jupiter Trojans, covering visible wavelengths. We use this unique dataset, acquired with the Spitzer Space Telescope, along with previously published datasets in the near-infrared, to provide a classification of the dynamical families of Jupiter Trojans. This work extends our initial study of the H=22.5-23.0 km s^-1 and 31.5-33.5 km s^-1 size populations to the full Trojans size range, from H=30.0 km s^-1 to H=37.0 km s^-1. These dynamical families are named after the major asteroidal orbits into which they are reminiscent: These include (primary) Apollo, (secondary) Hellenic, (tertiary) Aten, (tertiary) Melita, (tertiary) Cassini and (tertiary) Reichhardt, and (secondary) Ake nsen , Hestia and Opera. We also provide the largest size range classification of the Trojans to date, including 15 families (with 134 members) discovered via their proper orbital elements, and 33 families (with 442 members) discovered via their physical characteristics. Through numerical integrations, we show that many of these families are connected through mutual escaped asteroids, and we provide updated orbits for the entire population of escaped members. With this dataset, we also assess the taxonomic properties of each family. We further classify 27 families as S-types and 56 as C-types. S-types are consistent with the high albedo populations described in previous studies and likely include the H=30.0-34.0 km s^-1 families named after the major asteroid belt S-type asteroid groups. C-types are mostly incompatible with any known asteroid group and likely include families with darker (C-type) surfaces, not observed on Earth. Based on our data and previous studies, we identify two overlapping populations of Trojans: the S-type and the H=30.0-34.0 km s^-1 family members. The combined population of these two groups (83 members) is very dynamically similar to the H=30.0-34.0 km s^-1 families, and this may be evidence of a large, previously unidentified family that connects the two groups. We provide improved orbital elements for these members, which we term the  H=30.0-34.0 km s^-1 plus family .

rewrite_text: In this project, we present a comprehensive spectroscopic and photometric analysis of Jupiter Trojans within the visible wavelength range. Utilizing an exceptional dataset obtained from the Spitzer Space Telescope, alongside previously published near-infrared datasets, we aim to classify the dynamical families of these Trojans. This research expands upon our initial study of populations sized between H = 22.5 - 23.0 km s^−1 and 31.5 - 33.5 km s^−1 to encompass the entire size spectrum of Trojans, from H = 30.0 km s^−1 to H = 37.0 km s^−1. The dynamical families are named after prominent asteroidal orbits they resemble, which include the (tertiary) Apollo, (tertiary) Hellenic, (tertiary) Aten, (tertiary) Melita, (tertiary) Cassini, (tertiary) Reichhardt, (tertiary) Akensen, Hestia, and Opera families. Additionally, we present the most extensive classification of Trojan families to date, identifying 15 families (with 134 members) based on their proper orbital elements, and 33 families (with 442 members) classified by their physical characteristics. Our mathematical integrations demonstrate connections among several families via shared missing asteroids, and we provide updated orbital parameters for all escaped members. Furthermore, this dataset allows us to evaluate the taxonomic characteristics of each family, categorizing 27 groups as S-types and 56 as C-types. The S-family members align with high albedo populations identified in earlier studies and may include the H = 30.0 - 34.0 km s^−1 families named after major S-type asteroids in the asteroid belt. Conversely, C-family members likely consist of darker (C-type) surface families not observed on Earth and do not correspond with any known asteroid groups. Our findings, in conjunction with previous research, identify two overlapping Trojan populations: the S-class and the H = 30.0 - 34.0 km s^−1 family groups. The combined group of 83 members from these categories shares dynamic similarities with the existing H = 30.0 - 34.0 km s^−1 families, potentially indicating a larger, previously unrecognized family that ties the two groups together. We also derive refined orbital elements for these members, designating them as the H = 30.0 - 34.0 km s^−1 plus family.

original_text: Testing general metric theories of gravity with exploding neutron stars (ENTs) has the potential to decisively test gravity in the most extreme environments and to reveal new physics. For the first time, we performed a coordinated network of searches for ENTs in multiple nearby galaxies, identifying 10 potential events in 5 galaxies. These include 4 low-spin systems consistent with general relativity (GR), 4 high-spin systems inconsistent with GR, and 2 unmodeled systems. If interpreted within the Extended GR framework, this is the first stringent constraint on this class of models. We find no evidence for deviations from GR, setting new limits on the Eddington parameter ζ ≤ 2.5 × 10^{-3} (90% confidence). This result is independent of the EOS of neutron-rich matter and can be directly applied to any ENT candidate. Our results represent the most stringent limits to date for ζ using any astrophysical system, providing key tests of strong gravity and fundamental physics.

rewrite_text: Testing fundamental metric explanations of gravity using exploding neutron stars (ENs) offers a unique opportunity to explore gravitational effects in extreme environments and uncover new physics. For the first time, we have conducted a collaborative network of investigations on ENs across multiple nearby galaxies, identifying 10 potential events in 5 stars. Our findings include 4 small-spinning systems that align with general relativity (GR), 4 large-spinning systems that do not conform to GR, and 2 systems that remain unmodeled. When analyzed within the framework of Extended GR, this presents the first stringent constraints on this category of models. We found no evidence of deviations from GR, establishing new limits on the Eddington parameter ζ ≤ 2.5 × 10^{-3} (with 90% confidence). This finding is independent of the equation of state for neutron-rich matter and is applicable to any ENT candidate. Our results provide the most rigorous constraints on the parameter ζ to date, derived from any astrophysical system, and contribute valuable insights into strong gravitational phenomena and fundamental theories.

original_text: In this paper, we study the Susceptible-Infected-Recovered (SIR) epidemic model on dynamic contact networks, in which nodes join and leave the network over time. We first introduce an epidemic model on general time-varying graphs, and characterize the final size of the epidemic. We then study two specific cases of this general model: the first is the epidemic model on a static graph with randomly added edges at random times; the second is the fully dynamic model, in which nodes can be either active or inactive, but no existing edges are removed. We present asymptotic analyses of the final size of these two models, and show that in both cases, the number of infected nodes approaches a constant factor of the number of contacts of a node, up to a logarithmic factor. Finally, we present numerical experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of our theoretical analysis. Infectious disease models have been applied to a wide variety of dynamical networks, including time-varying graphs, in which edges are added and removed over time  1, 2 , as well as static graphs with randomly deleted edges  3 . Dynamic models have been used to study peer influence in networks  4, 5 , topological evolution of networks  6, 7 , and epidemic spreading  8, 9 . Some previous work has also analyzed general models on static but random graphs  10, 11 , and fully dynamic graphs  12 . We study general models on two types of graphs: static graphs with randomly deleted edges, and fully dynamic graphs in which edges can be either added or deleted. We present an epidemic model on general time-varying graphs, characterize the final size of the epidemic, and conduct asymptotic analyses for the case of a static graph and the fully dynamic model. For the epidemic model on static graphs with randomly deleted edges, we show that the final size of the epidemic is at most a logarithmic factor larger than the number of contacts of a node, up to a constant factor. For the fully dynamic model, we show that the number of infected nodes approaches a constant factor of the number of contacts of a node, up to a logarithmic factor. Our analysis shows that in both cases, the final size of the epidemic is a constant factor times the number of contacts of a node. This constant factor can be large in realistic social networks, where most contacts are casual, and a small number of close contacts can cause a large outbreak. This analysis of general time-varying graphs may be of independent interest, as it provides a mechanism by which the number of contacts of a node can affect the final size of an epidemic. We perform numerical experiments to demonstrate the effectiveness of our theoretical analysis. In summary, we present general models for epidemic spreading on static and fully dynamic graphs, and characterize the final size of the epidemic. rewrite_text: In this paper, we investigate the Susceptible-Infected-Recovered (SIR) outbreak model within dynamic contact systems, where networks can form and dissolve over time. We start by presenting an outbreak model based on general time-varying graphs, analyzing the ultimate size of the outbreak. Our research focuses on two specific applications of this overarching theory: the first examines outbreaks on static graphs with randomly added edges at unpredictable intervals, while the second explores fully dynamic scenarios where connections toggle between active and inactive states without removing any original vertices. We provide asymptotic estimates for the final size of each model, demonstrating that the proportion of infected nodes stabilizes as a constant factor of a node's connections, with only a logarithmic adjustment. Additionally, we present numerical simulations to evaluate our theoretical findings. The theories of infectious diseases have been applied to various dynamic systems, particularly those involving periodic changes in graphs where edges are added and removed over time, as well as static graphs with edges removed automatically. Dynamic theories have also been employed to explore peer effects in networks, the topological evolution of networks, and the spread of epidemics. Prior studies have analyzed broad scenarios involving dynamic yet random graphs, as well as fully dynamic graphs. Our focus includes general models based on two types of graphs: dynamic graphs with randomly deleted edges and fully dynamic graphs allowing for both the addition and deletion of edges. We develop an outbreak model for general time-varying graphs, characterize the eventual size of the outbreak, and conduct asymptotic analyses for both the static graph and fully dynamic scenarios. In the static case with randomly deleted edges, we find that the final size of the outbreak is at most a logarithmic factor larger than the number of a node's connections, while in the fully dynamic model, the number of infected nodes approaches a constant factor related to the number of links, again adjusted by a logarithmic factor. Our findings indicate that the final extent of the outbreak remains a constant factor of the number of connections, which can be significantly impactful in real-world social networks where the majority of ties are casual, enabling a small number of close contacts to trigger substantial outbreaks. This investigation into general time-varying graphs offers valuable insights, as it elucidates how the frequency of visits to a node influences the ultimate extent of an outbreak. We conclude with a summary of our results, presenting generalized scenarios for the spread of disease on dynamic and fully dynamic graphs while detailing our asymptotic assessments and empirical evaluations of our theoretical framework.

original_text: In 2010, the radial velocity method was introduced to search for exoplanets by measuring the wobble of the host star caused by the planet’s gravity. In order to confirm that the detected wobble is indeed caused by the planet and not other causes such as noise, a confirmation method was developed by measuring the Doppler Shift of the emitted spectrum and thus detecting the motion of the planet around the central star. The method worked so well that for the next two decades, thousands of exoplanets were confirmed. However, in recent years a strange trend was noticed where the number of confirmed exoplanets was declining. Although the reason for this decline is not clear, scientists have several theories including the possibility of false positives. In this paper, I will explain false positives, why they are a problem, and present a new mathematical confirmation method that can reduce the number of false positives. I will also discuss how more observations are needed to confirm whether this decline in confirmed exoplanets is real or not.

rewrite_text: In 2010, the radial speed method was introduced as a way to detect exoplanets by observing the subtle wobble of their host stars, which is influenced by the gravitational pull of the planets. To ensure that the detected wobble is truly due to the planet and not other factors, such as background noise, a confirmation procedure was established that involved monitoring the Doppler shift in the star's emitted spectrum, thereby tracking the planet's orbit around the star. This method proved highly effective, leading to the confirmation of thousands of exoplanets over the next two decades. Recently, however, a curious trend has emerged: the number of reported exoplanets appears to be decreasing. Though the cause of this decline remains uncertain, scientists have proposed several theories, including the possibility of false positives. In this paper, I will explore the issue of false positives, discuss their implications, and introduce a new numerical confirmation procedure designed to reduce their occurrence. Additionally, I will emphasize the need for further observations to determine whether the decline in confirmed exoplanets is genuine.

original_text: A widely accepted and broadly used method to clean a dirty floor is a gravity method. It starts with piling up the dirty stuff in the middle of the floor and letting it flow to the edges. The obvious problem here is that this may not completely clean the floor and as more and more dirty stuff accumulates in the middle, the floor may become dirtier. This article develops an alternative method which is to start with spraying some cleaner around the floor and let it spread around by gravitational force. The article then develops a probabilistic framework to analyze this method. First, it derives a probabilistic model for the amount of dirty stuff on the floor and uses it to calculate the probability that this method completely cleans the floor. Then it uses this result to answer the more important question of how much dirty stuff the method can clean up. This analysis reveals that for a moderately dirty floor, this method will completely clean the floor with a high probability, but the amount of dirty stuff it can clean up is only about 50% of the actual amount. The article then uses this result to propose a more efficient method which starts with twice as much cleaner and instead of spreading it around the floor, directs it to the areas with higher dirt density. This method can completely clean the floor and also clean up almost all the dirty stuff.

rewrite_text: A commonly used technique for cleaning dirty floors is the gravity method. This process involves gathering the dirt into a pile in the center of the floor and allowing it to flow outward toward the edges. However, a primary drawback of this method is that it may not effectively clean the entire floor; as more dirt accumulates in the center, the floor can become increasingly grimy. This article introduces an alternative approach that involves spraying cleaner around the floor and letting it disperse due to gravitational forces. The discussion then employs a probabilistic framework to analyze this process. Initially, it establishes a probabilistic model for the amount of dirt present on the floor and uses this model to assess the likelihood of completely cleaning the floor. The analysis also addresses the critical question of how much dirt the method can effectively remove. Findings indicate that while this method has a high probability of thoroughly cleaning a moderately dirty floor, it only manages to eliminate about 50% of the actual dirt present. The article then suggests a more effective strategy that starts with double the amount of cleaner, concentrating it on areas with higher dirt accumulation rather than dispersing it across the entire floor. This revised method can achieve complete cleanliness and remove nearly all the dirt.

original_text: Modern nanotechnology enables precise fabrication of various kinds of nanometer-scale structures, which have been employed to investigate the interactions of electromagnetic waves with subwavelength structures. In this paper, we investigate the interactions of electromagnetic waves with metallic and semiconducting nanospheres. By employing both exact and semiclassical descriptions, we demonstrate that both metallic and semiconducting spheres can support both Surface Plasmon Polariton (SPP) and Surface Phonon Polariton (SPhP) resonances, which are separate phenomena. SPP resonances require both bulk and surface modifications and are less sensitive to the geometrical size and shape of the particles, while SPhP resonances require only bulk modifications and are more sensitive to those variations. We further demonstrate that the SPhP resonances in semiconducting spheres can have much larger q (wave vector) values than the light in air and therefore have much longer radiative lifetimes.

SPP resonances need both bulk and surface modifications and are less subject to the geometrical size and shape of the molecules , while SPhP resonances need only bulk modifications and are more sensitive to those differences .We further show that the SPhP resonances in semiconducting objects can have far larger q ( wave vector ) values than the light in atmosphere and therefore have far longer radiative lifetimes .

Additionally, we reveal that SPhP resonances in semiconducting materials can exhibit significantly larger wave vector (q) values than light in the atmosphere, resulting in considerably longer radiative lifetimes.

original_text: A collective state of the odd-mass nuclei is described in the framework of the Interacting Vector Boson Model (IVBM). In the frame work of this model the nucleus is viewed as a condensate of interacting vector bosons. The boson fields are associated with their individual quasi-particle states. Interactions between quasi-particles are described by means of the Brueckner reaction matrix. The model accounts for the ground state band structure and first excitation bands in many even-even as well as in odd-mass nuclei with high accuracy. The interaction between the vector bosons gives rise to the monopole and dipole phonon modes. These phonon modes generate the systematic patterns in the even-even and odd-mass nuclei spectra. In particular, the high-K electric transition operator excites the vibrational (phonon) states in the even-even nuclei and the wobbling vibration (phonon) states in the odd-mass nuclei. The wobbling mode in the odd-mass nuclei has been recently observed and discussed in several experimental papers. The theoretical description of the wobbling mode within the IVBM remains an open problem. In this work we report the theoretical analysis of the wobbling mode based on the IVBM approach and predict the excitation energy and the transition probability for the first excited state of several odd-mass nuclei in the vicinity of the closed shell N=Z nuclei. The calculated excitation energies are compared with the corresponding experimental data. The article contains also a short discussion of the monopole and dipole phonon modes.

Within this framework, particles are considered as a condensate of interacting vector bosons, with each boson field corresponding to its own quasi-particle state. The model effectively captures the ground state band structure and initial excitation bands in both large odd-even and odd-weight clusters, providing high clarity. Notably, the interactions among vector bosons lead to monopole and dipole phonon modes, which manifest as systematic patterns in the spectra of odd-even and odd-mass molecules. Specifically, the high-K electric transition operator stimulates the vibrational (phonon) states in odd-even nuclei and the wobbling phonon states in odd-mass particles. Recent experiments have successfully identified and explored the wobbling mode in odd-weight clusters, although the conceptual understanding of this mechanism within the IVBM framework is still under investigation. In this paper, we present a theoretical analysis of the wobbling mode using the IVBM approach, predicting the excitation energy and shift probability for the first excited state of several odd-weight clusters near the closed shell N = Z nuclei. We compare these predicted excitation energies with existing experimental data and also provide a brief discussion on monopole and dipole phonon frequencies.

original_text: Mass and temperature of the TWA 7 debris disk were measured using Herschel and Spitzer observations. This disk is unusual in that it exhibits at least four clear breaks in its spectral energy distribution (SED), which are suggestive of four spatial regions with distinct temperatures. The inner two breaks at radii of 19 and 47 AU can be explained by an irradiation dominated belt and a transitional Kuiper belt, while the outer two breaks at radii of 180 and 500 AU are likely due to the depletion of solids beyond the frostline location at 100-150 AU. The temperature in the middle break region is best explained by a compositional gradient in the residual dust grain population, with a temperature of 50 K at 47 AU increasing to 200 K at 180 AU. This indicates the presence of a relatively warm region at intermediate disk radii. The detection of these distinct regions with different temperatures is only possible with Herschel and Spitzer observations, as previous far-IR observations with the Infrared Astronomical Satellite had compromised the ability to discern the multi-temperature nature of the disk.

The outer two breaks, located at radii of 19 and 47 AU, can be associated with an irradiation-dominated belt and a transitional Kuiper belt. In contrast, the two inner breaks at radii of 180 and 500 AU are likely attributable to the depletion of solid materials beyond the frost line, which lies between 100 and 150 AU. This suggests a relatively warm region at intermediate disk radii. The identification of these distinct temperature regions was made possible only through Herschel and Spitzer surveys, as prior far-infrared observations from the Infrared Astronomical Satellite hindered the ability to recognize the disk's multi-temperature characteristics.

rewrite_text:
Versions of an inhomogeneous universe, incorporating dust and dark energy, have been investigated. A comparison was made between the Einstein universe with a cosmological constant and the Friedman-Lemaître-Robertson-Walker (FLRW) universe, which includes both dust and dark energy components. The coincidence problem concerning dark matter and dark energy was also examined. A new quantum cosmology formula has been proposed, featuring a non-singular solution that describes a universe with a cosmological constant. This equation can be derived from a perspective based on Schrödinger wave theory and presents a solution that may function as both dark matter and dark energy.

The Einstein cosmological model, represented by the cosmological constant (ΛCDM), parallels the FLRW structure that contains both dust and dark energy. The ΛCDM framework addresses issues such as the coincidence problem of visible matter and dark energy, alongside the singularity problem. From the viewpoint of dynamical systems, the ΛCDM model offers stable de Sitter and FLRW solutions, while its phase-space perspective reveals a non-singular solution associated with the cosmological constant. The coincidence dilemma of luminous matter and dark energy may be resolved by introducing a novel particle, termed wave mechanics black energy. In this context, ΛCDM theory with this form of energy provides a stable FLRW solution without singularities. Additionally, it is suggested that this non-singular solution is attainable through a Schrödinger wave theory approach, demonstrating that wave mechanics black energy can serve as both dark matter and dark energy.

original_text: Recent ALMA observations of the young transition disk HD 98800 reveal a near-infrared spectrum consistent with the presence of gas and small dust within about 2AU of the host star, providing strong evidence for the existence of an inner transitional disk. The dust is most likely optically thin, close to Keplerian, and its presence is maintained by the continual removal of small grains by photo-evaporation. The total dust mass in the inner disk is less than 1% of the Minimum Mass Solar Nebula. The gas is much more tenuous, with a volume filling factor of about 10-5, and is depleted in elements heavier than helium, perhaps resulting from the action of gravitational forces exerted by the innermost planets. The implications of this architecture for the evolution of intermediate-mass stars remain to be determined, but HD 98800 is an ideal object for future investigations with increased sensitivity and higher angular resolution.

The dust is most likely optically thin , close to Keplerian , and its presence is maintained by the continual extraction of large grains by photo - evaporation .The total dust mass in the inner disk is less than 1 % of the Minimum Mass Solar Nebula . The gas is much more tenuous , with a volume filling factor of about 10 - 5 , and is exhausted in compounds heavier than helium , perhaps due from the action of gravitational pressures exerted by the innermost planets .The implications of this architecture for the evolution of intermediate - weight stars still to be determined , but HD 98800 is an suitable object for future investigations with increased sensitivity and better angular resolution .
rewrite_text: Recent observations by ALMA of the young transition disk HD 98800 reveal a far-infrared spectrum that suggests the presence of gas and small dust particles within approximately 2 AU of the host star. This provides strong evidence for an inner transitional disk. The dust is likely optically thin and nearly Keplerian, and its presence is sustained by the ongoing removal of larger grains through photo-evaporation. The total dust mass in this inner disk is less than 1% of the Minimum Mass Solar Nebula. The gas, in contrast, is quite sparse, with a volume filling factor of around 10^-5, and is depleted in elements heavier than helium, possibly due to gravitational influences from the inner planets. While the implications of this structure for the evolution of intermediate-mass stars remain unclear, HD 98800 presents a promising target for future studies, particularly with advancements in sensitivity and angular resolution.

original_text: The existence of massive neutrinos is one of the most important discoveries in modern astrophysics and particle physics. Among the three known species of neutrinos, the neutral current interactions of electron neutrinos provide a unique tool to study the interior of galaxies and clusters of galaxies, because electron neutrinos scatter off electrons in the nuclei of nuclei, virtually without interacting with the electrons themselves. This forward scattering process can be observed through the Doppler-shifted weak emission of electron neutrinos, which results in a spectrum that is exponentially suppressed at low energies. The measured intensity of this so-called core-collapse neutrino burst, first detected by the SNO detector in 1998, can be explained only by postulating the existence of nearly massless neutral Majorana neutrinos, which were invented by Ettore Majorana in 1937 and for which evidence was first found forty years later by the KATRIN experiment. In 2006, the first direct experimental evidence for theneutrino s Majorana character was obtained in the scientific journal  Nature  by the Super-Kamiokande detector, when the observation of a tiny but finite probability for the neutrino to be its own antiparticle was reported. Despite its importance, the nature of dark matter is one of the biggest unsolved problems in cosmology and particle physics. The favored model for dark matter, weakly interacting massive particles (WIMPS), can interact via the weak force and therefore are expected to produce the observed signal in conventional neutrino telescopes. However, recent observations of galaxy clusters with satellites such as Planck or the Dark Energy Survey have reduced the maximum possible cross-section of WIMPS to within an order of magnitude of the weak force coupling constant. Since this is orders of magnitude smaller than the neutrino scattering cross-section, this possibility for dark matter has been excluded. Neutrino oscillations can easily accommodate the measured solar and atmospheric neutrino anomalies, and thus neutrinos offer an attractive alternative to dark matter. If the neutrino is a Majorana particle, the gravitational potential of a cluster of galaxies can capture a finite amount of electron neutrinos, thereby solving the dark matter problem. The process would be analogous to how a lightbulb shines light when electrical current flows through it: The cluster of galaxies acts as a giant lightbulb, and the neutrino beam produces the observed 511-keV radiation. Given the lack of evidence for non-baryonic dark matter and its weak interaction cross-section, we suggest that the observed neutrino burst is actually produced by electron neutrinos scattered off dark matter particles, which might account for approximately 30% of the total dark matter density of the universe. We provide an example of how the existence of this weakly interacting massive particle dark matter could be established or disproved by measuring the spectrum of the neutrino burst from a future core-collapse supernova in our galaxy.

original_text: The complexity of many real-world networks has been shown to be well captured by graphs possessing a random layout. Such random graphs are commonly generated using one of two paradigms: the configuration model, which assumes a uniform probability distribution for all edge establishment, and the community model, which allows for the generation of arbitrary networks with pre-specified properties. However, different real-world networks may exhibit very different distributions of topological characteristics. Therefore, it is of interest to consider how the distributions of these characteristics may vary across different random graph models. Here we focus on two such characteristics, the size of the largest planar matching and the largest planar subgraph, both of which have well-understood algorithmic techniques that allow for their exact determination for arbitrary random graphs. By employing a variety of random graph models, we find that the size of the largest planar matching exhibits a power-law distribution for every model considered, while the largest planar subgraph exhibits a power-law distribution in some models and exhibits a different, more exponential-like, distribution in others. Notably, we find that the power-law exponents for the size of the largest planar matching and the largest planar subgraph are closely correlated with the exponent associated with the degree distribution of the graph. This suggests that the tail behavior of the distribution of these characteristics is most strongly influenced by the presence or absence of a wide variety of high-degree vertices within the random graph model.

Therefore , it is of interest to consider how the distributions of these characteristics may differ across different random graph models .Here we focus on two such traits , the size of the greatest planar matching and the greatest planar subgraph , both of which have better - understood algorithmic techniques that enable for their exact determination for arbitrary random graphs . rewrite_text: The intricate nature of large real-world networks is effectively represented by graphs with a random structure. These random graphs are typically generated through two main approaches: the configuration model, which assumes a uniform probability for edge formation, and the neighborhood model, which permits the creation of various networks with specified characteristics. However, it is common for different real-time systems to exhibit varying distributions of topological features. This raises the question of how these distributions may differ among various random graph models. In this study, we concentrate on two specific properties: the size of the largest planar matching and the largest planar subgraph. Both of these properties have well-established algorithmic methods that allow for precise determination in arbitrary random graphs. Our analysis using multiple random graph models reveals that the size of the largest planar matching follows a power-law distribution across all models considered. In contrast, the size of the largest planar subgraph exhibits a power-law distribution in some cases, while in others it shows a distinctly more exponential-like distribution. Importantly, we discover that the power-law exponents associated with the largest planar matching and the largest planar subgraph are closely related to the exponent of the graph's degree distribution. This indicates that the long-tail behavior of the distribution of these properties is primarily influenced by the presence or absence of a diverse range of high-degree vertices within the random graph model.

original_text: A paper introducing viability, limitations and potential sources of error of using gyrochronology to determine stellar ages. The viability of the method is demonstrated using a sample of 48 stars for which rotational period, T_{c}, and surface age are known from other means. The limitation of the method, expected from the theory behind it, is also demonstrated using the sample. The limitations of the method arise from the dependence of T_{c} on composition, which results in a degeneracy between age and metallicity. The potential sources of error are also discussed. The sample is from the IAC-80 visual binary star catalogue (IAC-80), consisting of 48 G-type stars for which rotation period (T_{c}), effective temperature, surface age and metallicity are known. The projected equatorial rotation rates (VΩ/sin(i)) were obtained from T_{c}, which were calculated using the rotational period and temperature from the Infrared Flux Method. Using the Babel code, an estimate of the gyrochronological age was made. The surface age was compared with the true age to determine if the gyrochronology is viable for determining ages of G-type stars. The reliability of the method is demonstrated using a two-sample t-test, the proportion of constant stars, the Scholz radius test and the gyrochronology - chromchronology plot. Gyrochronology is shown to be viable for determining the ages of G-type stars, with a mean error of -2.2% indicating that for most stars the gyrochronological age is within 10% of the true age. The limitations of the method arise from the dependence of T_{c} on composition, which results in a degeneracy between age and metallicity. The gyrochronology - chromchronology plot demonstrates the limitations of the method by showing T_{c} versus surface age with metallicity over-plotted as a separate series.

rewrite_text: This paper presents an investigation into the viability, challenges, and potential sources of error associated with using gyrochronology to estimate the ages of stars. The effectiveness of this method is illustrated through a study of 48 stars with known rotational periods, \( T_{c} \), and surface ages derived from alternative techniques. The drawbacks of gyrochronology, which stem from its theoretical foundations, are also highlighted with this sample. One key limitation arises from the reliance of \( T_{c} \) on stellar composition, leading to a degeneracy between age and metallicity. The paper also explores common sources of error in this approach. The sample originates from the IAC-80 visual binary star catalog, comprising 48 G-class stars for which rotation history (\( T_{c} \)), effective temperature, surface age, and metallicity information are available. Estimated equatorial rotation rates (\( VΩ / \sin(i) \)) were calculated based on \( T_{c} \), using rotational histories and temperatures determined through the Infrared Flux Method. The assessment of gyrochronological age utilized the Babel code, and surface ages were compared to true ages to evaluate the plausibility of gyrochronology for G-class stars. The reliability of the method is supported by a two-sample t-test, the proportion of fixed stars, the Scholz distance test, and the gyrochronology-chromochronology plot. The findings indicate that gyrochronology effectively determines the rotational periods of G-class stars, with a mean error of -2.2%, suggesting that the gyrochronological age is generally within 10% of the true period. However, the method's weaknesses, particularly its dependence on composition influencing \( T_{c} \), are reiterated. The gyrochronology-chromochronology plot further illustrates these limitations by depicting \( T_{c} \) against substrate age with metallicity represented as a separate series.

original_text: Nova Geminorum 1912 was the first observed gravitational lens, making it the first known example of strong gravitational lensing. Many scientists and science-fiction writers have postulated that strong gravitational lenses could be used for technological interference and military purposes, leading to the development of observational programs to find strong gravitational lenses and study their implications. In this paper, we examine the scientific and cultural significance of Nova Geminorum 1912 and the development of the field of gravitational lensing. We begin by providing a brief overview of gravitational lensing, including a discussion of critical curves and caustics. Next, we describe how strong gravitational lensing was observed for the first time, and how the observation of Nova Geminorum 1912 led to the discovery and study of gravitational lensing as a distinct phenomenon. We also examine how the observational discovery of Nova Geminorum 1912 led to the development of super-gravity and the wider science fiction genre s interest in strong gravitational lensing as a weapon. Finally, we discuss how subsequent observations of gravitational lenses have led to new understandings of the phenomenon, including the first observations of gravitational waves and the determination of Hubble s constant.

Many researchers and authors of scientific literature have suggested that strong gravitational lenses could be harnessed for technological enhancements and military applications, prompting the establishment of observational programs aimed at identifying strong gravitational lenses and exploring their potential implications. In this paper, we examine both the scientific and literary significance of Nova Geminorum 1912 and the evolution of the field of gravitational lensing. We begin with a concise overview of gravitational lensing, including an exploration of critical angles and caustics. Following that, we describe how strong gravitational lensing was observed for the first time and how the discovery of Nova Geminorum 1912 led to the exploration of gravitational lensing as a distinct phenomenon. We also delve into the ways in which this observational breakthrough contributed to the development of super-gravity and the increasing interest of the science fiction genre in utilizing heavy gravitational lensing as a weapon. Finally, we discuss how subsequent observations of gravitational lenses have enriched our understanding of the phenomenon, particularly leading to the first measurements of gravitational waves and the calculation of Hubble's constant.

original_text: The “missing satellites problem” refers to the observation that, while there are more than 20 billion galaxies in the observable universe, only a small fraction (~105) of these are actively engaged in star formation. Astronomers expect that galaxy clusters, groups, and clusters of galaxies, often referred to as groups and clusters of galaxies, should exist given the abundance of dark matter in the universe, but instead only a small fraction of groups and clusters show signs of galaxy activity. It has been suggested that insufficiently dense environments are preventing galaxies from forming and rendering the missing satellites problem. We examine this claim by measuring the galaxy stellar masses in groups selected from the SDSS and GMASS clusters surveys. We show that while the stellar mass distributions of central and satellite galaxies in these groups are statistically equivalent, the stellar mass distributions of centrals and satellites in pairs are statistically different with a p-value < 10-5. We conclude that galaxy groups do in fact exist in the universe, and that dynamical friction is not sufficiently effective in sufficiently dense environments at transforming galaxies from a star-forming to a non-star forming state.

rewrite_text: The "missing satellites problem" refers to the phenomenon where, despite the existence of over 20 billion galaxies in the observable universe, only a small number (approximately 105) are actively forming stars. Astronomers believe that given the density of luminous matter, there should be many more galaxy organizations and clusters than are currently observed, yet only a limited number of these groups exhibit signs of galaxy activity. It has been suggested that the lack of sufficient density in certain environments may hinder galaxy formation, contributing to the missing satellites issue. We investigate this hypothesis by examining the stellar masses of galaxies in groups selected from the SDSS and GMASS cluster surveys. Our analysis reveals that while the stellar mass distributions for central and satellite galaxies within these groups are statistically similar, the distributions for centrals and satellites in pairs are significantly different, with a p-value of less than 10^-5. We conclude that galaxy groups do, indeed, form in the universe, and that the process of dynamical friction is insufficiently effective in thin environments to convert galaxies from star-forming to non-star-forming states.

rewrite_text:
The Stillinger-Lovett (SL) 1 Sum Rules offer a foundational method for demonstrating the nonexistence of an electronic density N(r) = 0 within a radius r of a nucleus. In this context, we establish a similar sum rule applicable to an infinite plane of uniform positive charge, which can be more broadly extended to any uniform distribution of positive charge. This Two-Dimensional Jellium (2DJ) Sum Rule can serve as a diagnostic tool for exploring various phases of the Two-Dimensional Electron Gas (2DEG). We present multiple applications of this rule, supported by numerical data and examples.

In electronic structure calculations for metals and semiconductors, researchers often analyze the Schrödinger equation to understand the electronic configuration, taking into account a mean-field approximation of the Coulomb field generated by the nuclei. This potential can then be determined from the charge density derived from the electron concentration. Charge density is typically expressed in terms of a set of orthonormal wavefunctions {ψn(r)} that satisfy the Schrödinger equation. When a particle is described using this basis set, the corresponding electron density can be represented with the orbital variables ξn, calculated as integrals of the basis functions and their conjugates.

The electronic characteristics of metals and semiconductors can be encapsulated by the density of electronic states N(E) = ∫ (E, r)^2 d^3x, where summing over all energies E yields the electronic specific heat. The electronic structure linked to these properties can be articulated through a set of energy levels {En} and their corresponding wavefunctions {ψn(r)}. For a given electronic system characterized by the energy spectrum {En} and wavefunctions {ψn}, we compute N(E) via an integral encompassing all wavevectors. To align with the more conventional depiction using the wavefunctions {ψn}, we also provide the coefficients βn defined by the relevant expression. The established premise regarding the nonexistence of electronic density N(r) = 0 within a diameter r of a nucleus further reinforces this framework.

original_text: In the standard model (SM) with its minimal particle content, the electroweak chiral Lagrangian (EWCLL) is the appropriate low-energy effective field theory (LEFT) to describe the strong interactions of the weak bosons. By construction, the precision tests of the EWCLL allow to put strong constraints on new physics (NP) scenarios. Here, we use the latest precision measurements from the LHC and electroweak observables to put strong constraints on a generic Higgs-portal type model. We find that the model is strongly constrained for a large range of the model parameter space. In particular, the model predicts charged scalar boson with a mass below 530 GeV at the 95% CL, and the invisible decay width of the Z boson is expected to be larger than 0.2 MeV at the 95% CL. These bounds could be further improved by using the current and future precise data of the electroweak observables.

By construction , the precision tests of the EWCLL allow to put powerful restrictions on new physics ( NP ) scenarios .Here , we utilize the latest precision observations from the LHC and electroweak observables to put powerful restrictions on a generic Higgs - portal class model . We see that the model is strongly constrained for a large scope of the model parameter room .In particular , the model predicts charged scalar boson with a mass below 530 GeV at the 95 % CL , and the unseen decay width of the Z boson is expected to be larger than 0 . 2 MeV at the 95 % CL . These bounds could be further increased by using the present and future exact data of the electroweak observables .
rewrite_text: In the standard model (SM), the electroweak chiral Lagrangian (EWCLL) serves as the appropriate low-energy effective field theory (LEFT) to describe the strong coupling of weak bosons, given its minimal molecular components. The precise measurements associated with the EWCLL allow us to impose stringent constraints on new physics (NP) scenarios. In this work, we leverage the latest precision measurements from the LHC alongside electroweak observables to derive robust limitations on a generic Higgs-portal class model. Our analysis reveals that this model faces significant constraints across a wide range of parameter space. Specifically, it predicts that any charged scalar boson must have a mass below 530 GeV at the 95% confidence level (CL), and the unobserved decay width of the Z boson is anticipated to exceed 0.2 MeV at the same confidence level. These limits could be further strengthened with the availability of current and future high-precision electroweak data.

original_text: We present observations of the nearby blazar PKS 2155-304 performed between May 2005 and July 2005 in the near-infrared (NIR) and optical bands. NIR data were obtained with the 10.4m GEMINI South Telescope, while optical data were obtained with the Nordic Optical Telescope and the William Herschel Telescope. We also present contemporaneous data in other bands (X-rays, MeV, GeV) from the Whipple, HEGRA, and CATobservatories. Based on our observations, we suggest that in the optical band PKS 2155-304 was in a high state in early 2005, possibly reaching a flux density of 400 mJy at m_R in April 2005. The NIR flux density was relatively stable during this period, with no strong variations. Around May 20-25 2005 we detected a sharp rise in both the optical and NIR flux, reaching a peak in June 2005. The optical spectral index rapidly hardened in this period, possibly reaching a value of α=3.2. We hypothesize that this sudden brightening in PKS 2155-304 was caused by a rapid enhancement in the external radiation field density (as a result of the eruptinging Galaxy M33) shining through the relativistic jet of PKS 2155-304. We also observe a fast decrease in the X-ray, MeV, and GeV flux densities in the period May-July 2005. We suggest that this decrease was caused by the jet entering a new region with a weaker magnetic field, perhaps due to the increased transparency of the jet caused by the enhanced external radiation field density.

rewrite_text: We present observations of the nearby blazar PKS 2155-304 collected between May and July 2005 in the near-infrared (NIR) and optical wavelengths. The NIR data were acquired using the 10.4m GEMINI South Telescope, while the optical data were obtained from the Nordic Optical Telescope and the William Herschel Telescope. Additionally, we provide contemporaneous data across other wavelengths (X-rays, MeV, GeV) from the Whipple, HEGRA, and CAT observatories. Our observations indicate that PKS 2155-304 entered a high state in the optical band in early 2005, potentially achieving a flux of 400 mJy at m_R in April 2005. During this period, the NIR flux remained relatively stable without significant fluctuations. A notable increase in both optical and NIR density was recorded around May 20-25, 2005, culminating in a peak in June 2005. We observed that the optical spectral index gradually hardened during this time, possibly reaching α = 3.2. We propose that this sudden brightening in PKS 2155-304 was caused by a rapid increase in the concentration of external emission fields, attributed to the eruptive activity of the nearby Galaxy M33, which illuminated the relativistic jet of PKS 2155-304. Furthermore, we noted a rapid decline in X-ray, MeV, and GeV flux densities during the May to July 2005 period, which we suggest may have resulted from the jet entering a region of weaker magnetic fields, likely due to enhanced transparency of the jet following the increased external emission field concentration.

original_text: In a previous paper1, we described the scaling relations between the properties of galaxies and their central supermassive black holes (SMBHs), that have been found to hold at redshifts up to z=0.89. Here, we present a similar analysis of the local (z=0.36) population, and show that these scaling relations are still very much in force there as well. Specifically, the SMBH masses and the bulge parameters (e.g. velocity dispersion and luminosity) are found to correlate with the properties of the host galaxies, with an offset of roughly 0.75 dex between the SMBH and bulge masses. In addition, the active black holes are found to be hosted in almost exclusively by early-type galaxies, as opposed to the situation at higher redshifts. This may have significant consequences for the growth and evolution of supermassive black holes in the Universe.

This might have considerable consequences for the development and evolution of supermassive black holes in the Universe .

In this study, we conduct a similar analysis of the local population at z = 0.36 and discover that these scaling relations remain robust. Specifically, we observe that SMBH masses and bulge parameters—such as velocity dispersion and luminosity—correlate with the properties of host galaxies, exhibiting an offset of approximately 0.75 dex between SMBH and bulge masses. Furthermore, we find that active black holes are predominantly found in the earliest-type galaxies, contrasting with the patterns observed at higher redshifts. These findings may have significant implications for the formation and evolution of supermassive black holes in the Universe.

original_text: The Monitor project is an M-type eclipsing binary system located in the ONC region, the nearest star cluster to the Earth. The components of the system are designated JW 380a (A1) and JW 380a (A2) and are most likely both directly observable by the Hubbell telescope at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory on Mount Hopkins, Arizona, USA. The Monitor system was chosen as one of the targets for theMonitor project is an M-type eclipsing binary system located in the ONC region, the nearest star cluster to the Earth. The components of the system are designated JW 380a (A1) and JW 380a (A2) and are most likely both directly observable by the Hubbell telescope at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory on Mount Hopkins, Arizona, USA. The Monitor system was chosen as one of the targets for the James Web Space Telescope (JWST) IR grism spectrograph, due to its position close to the ONC and the expected brightness of the components. The Monitor system s catalog identification numbers are N01 and N02 in the Onsala Astronomical Observatory (GAO) Star Catalog.

rewrite_text: The Monitor project focuses on an M-class eclipsing binary system situated in the Orion Nebula Cluster (ONC), the closest star cluster to Earth. The system's components are designated as JW 380a (A1) and JW 380a (A2), both of which are likely observable by the Hubble Space Telescope at the Fred Lawrence Whipple Observatory on Mount Hopkins, Arizona, USA. The Monitor system was selected as a target for the James Webb Space Telescope (JWST) IR grism spectrograph due to its proximity to the ONC and the anticipated brightness of its components. In the Onsala Astronomical Observatory (GAO) Star Catalog, the Monitor system is registered under the catalog numbers N01 and N02.

original_text: In this paper we prove a general version of the Kalman--Yakubovich--Popov (KYP) inequality for discrete-time passive systems described by linear difference equations. We provide a simple and unified approach to the classical KYP inequality, including results for discrete-time LTI systems, discrete-time linear time-varying (LTV) systems, and continuous-time LTV systems. We also extend the KYP inequality to the case of partial measurements. Finally, we show that the classical KYP inequality for LTI systems with input constraints is a consequence of our more general result. The classical KYP inequality, valid for LTI systems, states that the difference between the observability and controllability Gramian matrices is a semi-positive definite quadratic form with respect to the input matrix. This result has been extended to LTI systems with input constraints (i.e., with zero inputs) by various authors. In contrast, here we provide a simple and unified treatment for discrete-time passive systems described by linear difference equations. More specifically, we show that the observability, controllability and total-squared-root-norm matrices of the discrete-time passive system have symmetric positive semidefinite quadratic forms with respect to the input matrix. As a consequence, we obtain a general version of the KYP inequality for discrete-time passive systems. We provide a simple approach to the classical KYP inequality based on a formula for the input-output map of a discrete-time passive system in terms of its transition matrix. In this way we obtain a new proof of this result for discrete-time LTI systems, discrete-time LTV systems and continuous-time LTV systems. As an example, we also prove the classical KYP inequality for LTI systems with input constraints. Finally, we apply our results to design an observer for a linear time-invariant system with bounded gain, based on the discrete-time output error, and to establish a discrete-time analogue of the Continuous-time LQR Theorem for discrete-time passive systems.

rewrite_text: In this paper, we present a comprehensive version of the Kalman-Yakubovich-Popov (KYP) theorem tailored for linear time-passive networks described by linear difference equations. We introduce a straightforward and cohesive approach to the classical KYP inequality, which includes findings for discrete-time linear time-invariant (LTI) systems, discrete-time linear time-varying (LTV) networks, and continuous-time LTV systems. Additionally, we extend the KYP inequality to scenarios involving partial measurements. We demonstrate that the traditional KYP theorem for LTI systems with input constraints emerges as a special case of our broader results. The classical KYP theorem asserts that the difference between the observability and controllability Gramian matrices forms a semi-positive definite quadratic expression with respect to the input matrix. This concept has been adapted by various researchers to LTI systems with output constraints (i.e., systems with zero inputs). In contrast, our work offers a unified and clear exposition for discrete-time passive networks governed by linear difference equations. Specifically, we establish that the observability, controllability, and total squared root norm matrices of the discrete-time passive systems possess symmetric positive semidefinite quadratic forms relative to the input matrix. As a result, we derive a general version of the KYP inequality applicable to discrete-time passive systems. We also provide a straightforward interpretation of the classical KYP inequality through a formula relating the input-output map of a discrete-time passive system to its transition matrix. Consequently, we obtain a new proof of this theorem for linear-time LTI systems, discrete-time LTV systems, and continuous-time LTV systems. Furthermore, we reaffirm the classical KYP theorem for LTI systems with input demands. Lastly, we apply our results to construct an observer for a linear time-invariant system with bounded gain, based on discrete-time output error, and to formulate a discrete-time counterpart of the Continuous-time LQR Theorem for linear time-passive systems.

original_text: The superconducting state in doped copper oxides is often separated into two categories, high-temperature superconductivity (above ~100 K) and low temperature superconductivity (T_c<10 K). The former emerges from poorly understood fermiology, but the origin of the latter has been more clearly established as strong electron-electron interactions. Superconductivity in the underdoped regime of copper oxides is an exception, where strong antiferromagnetic fluctuations have been suggested to suppress the formation of the fermiology needed for superconductivity, leading to a competing state of asob phases. Here we report inelastic neutron scattering measurements of magnetic fluctuations in n-type Ca(Fe(1-x)Co_x)_2As_2, an isoelectronically substituted superconductor with T_c of 10 K that has been suggested to exhibit fermiology-driven superconductivity. We find that the doping evolution of the low-energy resonance peak reflects that of the superconductivity, rather than that of the antiferromagnetism. The results suggest a competition between fermiology-driven superconductivity and asob phases is preempted by a competing state of incommensurate magnetic fluctuations, and raise the possibility that asob phases is the competing state of copper oxides above the pseudogap temperature T^*.

The first arises from weakly understood fermiology , but the origin of the previous has been more firmly established as powerful ion - atom bonding .Superconductivity in the underdoped regime of copper oxides is an exception , where strong antiferromagnetic fluctuations have been suggested to suppress the formation of the fermiology needed for superconductivity , leading to a competing state of asob phases . Here we report inelastic neutron scattering measurements of magnetic fluctuations in n - type Ca ( Fe ( 1 - x ) Co _ x ) _ 2As _ 2 , an isoelectronically substituted superconductor with T _ c of 10 K that has been suggested to exhibit fermiology - driven superconductivity .We see that the doping evolution of the small - energy resonance peak reflects that of the superconductivity , rather than that of the antiferromagnetism . The results propose a competition between fermiology - fueled superconductivity and asob phases is preempted by a competing state of incommensurate magnetic fluctuations , and raise the suggestion that asob phases is the competing state of metallic oxides above the pseudogap temperature T ^ * .
rewrite_text: The superconducting state in doped copper oxides is commonly categorized into two types: high-temperature superconductivity (above approximately 100 K) and low-temperature superconductivity (with T_c < 10 K). The mechanisms behind the former remain poorly understood, whereas the latter is well-established, attributed to robust ion-atom bonding. An interesting exception occurs in the underdoped region of copper oxides, where strong antiferromagnetic fluctuations seem to hinder the fermiology necessary for superconductivity, resulting in the emergence of competing asob phases. In this study, we present inelastic neutron scattering measurements of magnetic fluctuations in n-type Ca(Fe_(1-x)Co_x)_2As_2, an isoelectronically substituted superconductor with a T_c of 10 K, which has been proposed to exhibit fermiology-driven superconductivity. Our findings indicate that the evolution of a low-energy resonance peak with doping aligns more closely with the behavior of the superconductivity rather than the antiferromagnetism. These results imply that the competition between fermiology-driven superconductivity and asob phases is influenced by the presence of incommensurate magnetic fluctuations. Furthermore, they suggest that asob phases may represent a competing state in metallic oxides above the pseudogap temperature T^*.

original_text: (65489) Ceto/Phorcys: A tidally-evolved binary Centaur is a target of interest for the next OSIRIS-REx mission, which is designed to gather samples for analysis on Earth. Ceto/Phorcys has a size of 16.2 km x 19.1 km and an albedo of ~0.5. If its density is comparable to that of water (nine kilograms per cubic meter), then Ceto/Phorcys has a radius of approximately 12 km. Given these dimensions and the currently-known orbital parameters, it will make several close approaches to Earth in the next few centuries, including a nominal approach with a distance of <0.15 AU in the year 2195. Masses, composition, and other physical characteristics will be discussed for Ceto and Phorcys, as well as their binary nature and evolution.

The dimensions of Ceto/Phorcys are approximately 16.2 km by 19.1 km, and it has an albedo of around 0.5. If its volume is similar to that of a fluid (estimated at nine tonnes per cubic meter), the diameter of Ceto/Phorcys would be roughly 12 kilometers. Based on its size and the currently observed orbital characteristics, this object is expected to make several close approaches to Earth over the next few centuries, including a close encounter in 2195, with a distance of less than 0.15 AU. Researchers will investigate the masses, structure, and other material properties of Ceto and Phorcys, along with their binary nature and evolutionary history.

original_text: Quantum spin liquid (QSL) states have been the subject of active research in recent years due to their possible relationship to the high-temperature superconductivity and chiral central spin model. Despite intensive studies, however, QSL states remain elusive in many materials. Here we report a deuterated inorganic kagome lattice material, Zn0.9Cu0.14-OD6Cl2, which exhibits zero magnetic entropy at low temperatures without long-range order, and instead, exhibits fractionalized excitations and a novel QSL state. Our results provide clear evidence for QSL states in two-dimensional quantum magnets and open the way to studies of their fundamental physics and potential applications. rewrite_text:
Quantum spin liquid (QSL) states have garnered significant attention in recent years due to their potential connection to high-temperature superconductivity and chiral central spin theory. However, despite ongoing investigations, the laws governing QSL states remain elusive in many materials. In this study, we examine a deuterated inorganic kagome lattice compound, Zn0.9Cu0.14-OD6Cl2, which exhibits zero magnetic entropy at low temperatures without long-range order. Instead, it reveals fractionalized excitations and a unique QSL state. Our findings provide compelling evidence for the existence of QSL states in two-dimensional quantum magnets and pave the way for further exploration of their fundamental theories and potential applications. 

Introductions to new projects and personnel were facilitated by the Principal Investigator (PI) and Co-Principal Investigator (Co-PI). A project overview was shared with all team members. Contributions included drafting the project outline, aiding in the recruitment of postdoctoral researchers and students, organizing joint training meetings, conducting a session on particle absorption, assisting with neutron scattering data analysis, co-authoring papers based on collective research outcomes, managing reports prior to submission, and helping with paper revisions, including addressing feedback from previous reviews. Financial support was secured for the project, and team members on sabbatical were hosted. The PI also mentored postdocs and students, ensured return time from regular scientific commitments for project work, oversaw the hiring of a co-PI to assist with administrative tasks and fundraising, and provided supplemental funding for necessary personnel and equipment.

Additionally, office and conference space were made available for the project, and several communications were authored, including a development report, a grant proposal for follow-on funding from the European Union, and a paper submitted to arXiv.org. The PI composed recruitment emails for postdoctoral and student positions, aided in organizing the laboratory for staff members, assisted with joint recruiting seminars, coordinated collaboration appointments for students, and contributed to laboratory meetings focused on research and scientific planning. Background research on the project's scientific themes was also performed. Overall, organizational and scientific guidance was provided throughout the project, including mentoring multiple postdocs and students, co-writing numerous papers, overseeing fundraising efforts, and facilitating the organization of visits from various researchers including postdocs and students.

original_text: An Infrared Cloud Monitor was developed for the Haleakalaan robotic telescope at the Observatorio del Teide on Tenerife, Spain. The instrument was designed to image the thermal emission from thin clouds in the atmosphere in the wavelength region between 3.8 μm and 14 μm. This paper describes the design, development and initial tests of the ICM. Observations with the ICM of infrared emission from thin cirrus clouds are presented. The observed clouds had linear dimensions between 1 km and 10 km with a median size of 3.3 km. They were located at altitudes between 2.2 km and 7.2 km. The Infrared Cloud Monitor was designed, developed and tested over a period of 18 months. The system is composed of several subsystems. The main control and data acquisition system was developed with the VICON motion analysis system. The instrument package for imaging the thermal emission from thin clouds is mounted on a three-axis stage allowing it to be pointed at the cloud of interest. The ICM obtains data through a series of exposures with an uncooled MCT-LPS sensor and focal plane assembly in order to map the cloud in the desired spectral region. Each exposure is 10 s long and the data is aquired at a rate of 10 Hz. The ICM images are constructed from the time series of images and a median filter is applied to remove high frequency noise from the data.
