rewrite_text:
Bicategories can be understood as specialized types of categories, featuring two-sided cells and functioning within a framework of four-class assemblies. These structures serve as generalizations of monoids with two elements, organized into categories where the fibers form a two-category with a single object. A framed bicategory is defined as an enriched category within the realm of bicategories, incorporating three-sided cells and classified within a six-class system, along with associated hom-bicategories that correspond to an eight-class structure. These framed bicategories can be seen as generalizations of 2-objects, where the fiber is a 2-groupoid with just one 2-morphism. 

Monoidal fibrations between two framed bicategories are characterized as weak functors linking their underlying categories while loosely adhering to additional equations. These fibrations play a crucial role in capturing the 2-cells within the fibers. They also extend the concepts of crossed modules of 2-families and strict monoidal functors from monoidal categories. When a bicategory is framed with three-sided cells, it transforms into an enriched classification system, maintaining six-class components. The paper delves into the study of framed bicategories, their 2-cells, and monoidal fibrations from various perspectives, elucidating key concepts and constructions. 

Important points discussed in this framework include:
- Bicategories as specialized categories
- Two-sided cells as generalizations of one-element sets
- Four-class assemblies as extensions of two-element sets
- Framed bicategories representing enriched types
- Fibers functioning as 2-categories with 2-cells acting as 2-morphisms
- 2-groups forming the fibers of strict monoidal functors
- Morita equivalence of 2-groups reflected as isomorphisms between the corresponding strict monoidal functors
- Crossed rings of 2-groups interpreted as monoidal deformations of relevant 2-groups
- Monoidal fibrations connecting framed bicategories akin to strict monoidal functors, while weakly adhering to extra equations and relating to fibers as 2-groupoids.

Additionally, generalizations of these concepts are discussed, along with appendices that provide technical insights.

original_text: This paper defines universal invariants for higher K-theory and higher signatures, and demonstrates their relevance by determining higher K-theory of one-point compactifications of hyperbolic groups. These universal invariants satisfy the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence for topological K-theory, a calculation of the fundamental group, and the universal coefficients theorem. In this framework, the strong Novikov conjecture, which states that the higher signatures of a closed manifold are universal among degree-one cohomology classes, is equivalent to the homotopy invariance of higher K-theory. This implies that the higher K-groups satisfy the Hirzebruch signature theorem, and, under certain hypotheses, also detect exotic elements in the stable homology of manifolds. We also establish twisted versions of these universal invariants and apply them to the Bismut intersection formula, the Borel regulator, and elliptic genera. This approach to higher K-theory and universal invariants extends to other stable homotopy theories, such as bordism and generalized cohomology. In particular, we define twisted variants of these theories and show how to compute these variants using the invariants defined here. This approach unifies the study of K-theory, bordism, generalized cohomology, and stable homotopy by viewing these theories as localizations of a single universal theory of stable derived functors. In particular, the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence for topological K-theory arises as the key element in the localization process. In addition to defining this universal theory of stable derived functors, we also calculate its rationalization. This provides a powerful way to determine the rational homology of one-point compactifications of hyperbolic groups, which may be of independent interest. Finally, we propose a framework for studying twisted stable homotopy theories in which various structures, such as vector bundles and operators, are replaced by connective coverings and corresponding universal invariants. We indicate some examples of these twisted theories and indicate how to compute their universal invariants. I thank David Giesen, Sean Tammar, and Robert Yager for their advice and support. This is a pro-spectrum, or internal homology theory, meaning it admits a normalized complex with homology the homotopy groups of the K-theory spectrum KU. These homotopy groups may be given the structure of a ring by means of coefficients; the Hopkins-Miller theorem identifies this ring as topological cyclic homology TC, allowing K-theory to be studied via universal properties. This pro-spectrum includes a lot of information. The fundamental theorem of K-theory describes it as a collection of pieces separated by unique extensions, whose cancellation requires the Elliott invariant. Meanwhile, the periodicity theorem and Bott periodicity isomorphism generalize the classical Bott periodicity and result respectively to the pro-spectrum level. There is also

rewrite_text:
This paper introduces universal invariants for higher K-theory and enlarged signatures, illustrating their significance by differentiating the higher K-theory of one-point compactifications of hyperbolic groups. These universal invariants adhere to the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence associated with topological K-theory, calculations of fundamental groups, and the universal coefficients theorem. Within this framework, the strong Novikov theorem—which asserts that the higher signatures of a closed manifold are intrinsic to degree-one cohomology groups—parallels the homotopy invariance of higher K-theory. Consequently, this suggests that the higher K-families are consistent with the Hirzebruch signature theorem and, under specific conditions, also exhibit exotic components within the stable homology of manifolds. Furthermore, we develop twisted versions of these universal invariants and extend their application to the Bismut interchange formula, the Borel regulator, and elliptic genera. Our approach to higher K-theory and universal invariants is applicable to other stable homotopy theories, including bordism and generalized cohomology. Specifically, we define twisted forms of these theories and demonstrate how to compute these variants using the invariants introduced herein. This methodology provides a unifying perspective on K-theory, bordism, generalized cohomology, and stable homotopy by treating these theories as localizations of a singular universal theory of stable derived functors, with the Atiyah-Hirzebruch spectral sequence for topological K-theory emerging as a central component in this localization process. Alongside the definition of this universal theory of stable derived functors, we also delineate its rationalization, which offers a robust approach for deriving the rational homology of one-point compactifications of hyperbolic groups, potentially holding independent significance. Lastly, we propose a framework for investigating twisted stable homotopy theories, wherein various elements, such as vector bundles and operators, are substituted with connective coverings and corresponding universal invariants. We provide examples of these twisted theories and suggest methods for calculating their universal invariants. I extend my gratitude to David Giesen, Sean Tammar, and Robert Yager for their guidance and support. 

Higher K-theory, through universal invariants, encapsulates essential aspects of smooth cohomology by addressing all homotopy classes simultaneously. This concept represents a pro-spectrum or an internal homology notion, wherein it possesses a normalized complex whose homology aligns with the homotopy classes of the K-theory spectrum KU. These homotopy categories can be shown to compose a ring through the use of coefficients; the Hopkins-Miller formula identifies this ring as topological cyclic homology TC, facilitating the examination of K-theory via universal properties. This pro-spectrum harbors substantial information. The fundamental premise of K-theory portrays it as a group of segments interconnected by unique extensions, whose closure necessitates the Elliott invariant. Simultaneously, the periodicity hypothesis and the Bott periodicity isomorphism extend the classical Bott periodicity and results to the pro-spectrum context.

original_text: We present a catalog of 98,653 discrete sources detected in the three quarters of the 5 square degrees of the Carina Nebula surveyed by the Gaia Survey in its first visit to this region of the Milky Way. We use this catalog, in combination with the much deeper catalog of sources detected in the entire Carina Nebula Survey published in a companion paper, to study global properties of the Carina Nebula and its distribution across the energy spectrum. We find that the Nebula has an energy budget of 6 - 21%, rising to 21 - 30% in its densest regions. The Nebula is most homogeneously distributed around 6% in the region surrounding the HII region Trion Nebula and most clumpy toward its south and west, in a pattern typical of sequential energy injection. We show that this clumpiness has an environmental origin, with dense gas in Carina being shielded from external influences and having a lower density than the less dense ISM in the surrounding areas.
watermark_text: We create a list of 98 , 653 discrete sources detected in the three third of the 5 square degrees of the Carina Nebula surveyed by the Gaia Survey in its initial visit to this region of the Milky Way . We use this catalog , in combination with the much deeper catalog of sources detected in the entire Carina Nebula Survey published in a companion paper , to study global properties of the Carina Nebula and its distribution across the energy spectrum .We see that the Nebula has an energy budget of 6 - 21 % , rising to 21 - 30 % in its densest areas . The Nebula is most homogeneously scattered around 6 % in the region surrounding the HII region Trion Nebula and most clumpy toward its east and west , in a pattern typical of sequential power injection .We indicate that this clumpiness has an environmental origin , with heavy gas in Carina being shielded from external influences and having a smaller density than the less dense ISM in the nearby areas .
rewrite_text: We compiled a list of 98,653 distinct sources identified in one third of the 5 square degrees of the Carina Nebula examined during the Gaia Survey's initial exploration of this region of the Milky Way. This catalog, along with a much more comprehensive dataset from the entire Carina Nebula Survey presented in a related study, allows us to investigate the overall characteristics of the Carina Nebula and its distribution across the energy spectrum. Our findings reveal that the Nebula possesses an energy budget ranging from 6% to 21%, which increases to between 21% and 30% in its densest regions. The energy distribution is relatively uniform, averaging around 6% in the vicinity of the HII region known as Trion Nebula, but appears more clumpy toward the east and west, displaying a pattern characteristic of sequential power injection. We suggest that this clumpiness stems from environmental factors, as the dense gas in the Carina Nebula is shielded from external influences and has a lower density compared to the less dense interstellar medium in surrounding areas.

original_text: The strong chemical bonds in molecules and the high opacity of particules in medium to low temperatures limit the study of Ultracool Dwarfs (UCDs) and Exoplanets. The most massive UCDs have a temperature lower than 20000 K and an effective temperature below 300 K; they are in a gaseous state. The Opacity Project (OP) computes theoretical line and mean opacities for plasmas of different temperatures and compositions, which can be used as input for radiative-transfer simulations and then to fit the observed spectra of these UCDs and Exoplanets. In this work, the authors compute line and mean opacities for plasmas with temperatures lower than 20000 K and effective temperatures lower than 300 K. The inclusion of impurities and traces of metals (like H2O, CO2, NH3, CH4, etc.) extend the computed range of opacities for such kind of plasmas. For example, for plasmas at 10000 K with 90% Hydrogen and 10% Carbon, the authors computed line and mean opacities within 10% of the OP simulation results for pressures between 10-7 and 10-9 torr. Thus, these computed line and mean opacities can be used to simulate the thermal emission and reemission spectra of UCDs and Exoplanets with good accuracy.

The most large UCDs have a temperature lower than 20000 K and an effective heat below 300 K ; they are in a gaseous state .The Opacity Project ( OP ) computes theoretical line and mean opacities for plasmas of different conditions and compositions , which can be used as input for radiative - transfer simulations and then to fit the known spectra of these UCDs and Exoplanets . rewrite_text: The robust chemical bonds present in compounds and the significant opacity of particles at medium to low temperatures pose challenges in studying Ultracool Dwarfs (UCDs) and Exoplanets. The largest UCDs typically have temperatures below 20,000 K and effective temperatures under 300 K, existing in a gaseous state. The Opacity Project (OP) calculates theoretical line and mean opacities for plasmas with various conditions and compositions, providing crucial data for radiative-transfer simulations to match observed spectra of UCDs and Exoplanets. In this research, the authors calculate line and mean opacities for plasmas with temperatures under 20,000 K and effective pressures below 300 K. By incorporating impurities and trace metals (such as H2O, CO2, NH3, CH4, etc.), the scope of computed opacities for these plasmas is expanded. For example, they found that for plasmas at 10,000 K with 90% Hydrogen and 10% Carbon, the computed line and mean opacities were within 10% of the OP simulation data for pressures between 10^-7 and 10^-9 torr. Consequently, these computed line and mean opacities can effectively be used to simulate the thermal decay and reemission spectra of UCDs and Exoplanets with high sensitivity.

original_text: L Univers en expansion est une expérience menée par Lawrence Krauss qui consistait à faire fondre un métal à température constante à une température croissante pour observer les effets d entropie générés. L expérience a été menée dans trois lieux différents suivant la température auquel le métal a été chauffé. La première étape correspond à une température de 330°C, entre 330°C et 310°C la chaleur produite était suffisante pour alimenter un château de jeu, mais les résultats étaient contradictoires. Après avoir fondu à la température de 310°C, le métal a été tempéré au noyau d un certain nombre de heures, la raison principale pour laquelle le noyau a durci est que les atomes étaient partis en expansion dans le vide à la vue de puissants jets de rayons X. De nombreuses expériences ont montré qu il s agissait d une expérience réussie, mais d autres scientifiques ont soutenu que les résultats obtenus n étaient pas valides en raison de l absence de chaleur de ce noyau allumé. La chaleur produite a été insuffisante pour faire fondre les blocs de métal et pour générer l entropie nécessaire pour les preuves avancées. L expérience a également comporté un problème en termes d énergie, car le métal doit être chauffé à très haute température alors qu il est composé principalement de piles au cours du métal ces dernières utilisent de l énergie considérablement plus efficacement. L Univers en expansion est un rapport par Lawrence Krauss, où il présente les conclusions d une expérience menée dans le but d étudier les effets d entropie générées, à la lumière de récents développements, Krauss soumet l expérience qu il a menée pour révision. La critique se concentre principalement sur l absence de chaleur produite par le noyau, qui aurait pu générer les effets d entropie postulés. Selon les estimations de Krauss, la chaleur produite par le noyau ne serait pas suffisante pour faire fondre les blocs de métal, alors qu elles le répondent entièrement. Cette proposition entraînerait une é

rewrite_text: L'Univers en expansion est le titre de l'expérience conduite par Lawrence Krauss, qui visait à faire fondre un métal à une température constante tout en observant les effets de l'entropie engendrée par la hausse de la température. L'expérience a été réalisée à trois endroits différents, avec des températures variant suivant le métal chauffé. La première étape a été menée à 330°C ; entre 330°C et 310°C, la chaleur produite était suffisante pour alimenter un château de jeu, mais les résultats se sont révélés contradictoires. Après fusion à 310°C, le métal a été tempéré pendant plusieurs heures. La principale raison pour laquelle une partie du métal a durci réside dans l'expansion des atomes dans le vide, sous l'influence de puissants rayons X. Bien que de nombreuses expériences aient montré que celle-ci a été un succès, d'autres scientifiques ont contesté la validité des résultats, arguant que l'absence de chaleur produite par le noyau était problématique. En effet, la chaleur générée n'était pas suffisante pour faire fondre les blocs de métal et générer l'entropie nécessaire aux preuves avancées. Un autre souci soulevé par l'expérience était d'ordre énergétique, car il fallait chauffer le métal à des températures très élevées, alors qu'il serait plus efficace de se servir de piles directement. Dans son rapport, Krauss présente ses observations issues de l'expérience dans le but d'étudier les effets de l'entropie générée. À la lumière des développements récents, il soumet son expérience à révision. Les critiques portent surtout sur le manque de chaleur produite par le noyau, qui aurait pu engendrer les effets d'entropie postulés. Selon les estimations de Krauss, la chaleur produite par le noyau ne suffirait pas à faire fondre les blocs de métal, malgré une réponse plus globale sur la question. Cette proposition soulève une série de questions.

original_text: A singly negatively charged self-assembled InGaAs quantum dot with a effective Landé g factor of -0.44 was studied in a noncollinear magnetic field. By using optically detected electron spin resonance, we measured electron and hole spin relaxation times exceeding 4.5 μs and 0.7 ms, respectively. The long hole spin relaxation time greatly exceeded the values predicted by the Fermi’s golden rule and the Hölder inequality, and was consistent with the best theoretical estimates for GaAs with conduction band effective mass. We argue that the unexpectedly long hole spin relaxation time is the result of the suppression of electron-hole correlation-induced transitions between the heavy-hole valence band and the split-off conduction band induced by the strong quantum dot vertical confinement. The authors would like to thank Dr. Roman Skrotski for fruitful discussions and providing experimental data. This work was supported by the Foundation for Polish Science (FNP).

We argue that the unusually long hole spin relaxation time is the result of the disruption of electron - hole correlation - mediated transitions between the heavy - hole valence band and the split - off conduction band caused by the strong quantum dot vertical confinement .The authors would like to thank Dr . rewrite_text: A negatively charged self-assembled InGaAs quantum dot, characterized by an effective Landé g-factor of -0.44, was investigated in a noncollinear magnetic field. Utilizing optically detected electron spin resonance, we measured electron and hole spin relaxation times exceeding 4.5 μs and 0.7 ms, respectively. The observed long hole spin relaxation time significantly exceeded the predictions made by Fermi's golden rule and Hölder's inequality, aligning instead with the most accurate theoretical estimates for GaAs, considering its conduction band effective mass. We propose that the exceptionally prolonged hole spin relaxation time stems from the disruption of electron-hole correlation-mediated transitions between the heavy-hole valence band and the split-off conduction band, induced by the strong vertical confinement within the quantum dot. The authors express their gratitude to Dr. Roman Skrotski for valuable discussions and the provision of empirical data. This research was supported by the Foundation for Polish Science (FNP).

original_text: Tri-bimaximal neutrino mixing, proposed in 1998 by H. Liu and X. Zhang, has been regarded as one of the best models for the mixing of neutrinos, and has gained increasing attention recently  1,2 . The tri-bimaximal neutrino mixing angle θ_{23} can be expressed as 2/9π - 1/9, and the deviation from the maximal mixing angle can be viewed as a perturbation parameter α. The latest neutrino experimental results show that the neutrino mixing angles are running away from tri-bimaximal neutrino mixing. In this paper, we consider a type-II seesaw mechanism with an additional singlet lepton and generate the baryon asymmetry of the universe through leptogenesis. We will show that the perturbation parameter α can be derived from the baryon asymmetry of the universe. The absolute values of the perturbation parameters for the mixing angles θ_{23}, θ_{13}, and δ are 0.09, 0.047, and 0.014, respectively. We find that these absolute values are all compatible with the current experimental results.

Zhang in 1998, is considered one of the leading approaches for understanding neutrino mixing and has recently garnered increasing attention. The tri-bimaximal mixing angle θ_{23} can be expressed as \( \frac{2}{9\pi} - \frac{1}{9} \), with the deviation from the maximal mixing angle treated as a perturbation parameter, α. Recent experimental findings indicate that the actual neutrino mixing angles deviate from the tri-bimaximal predictions. In this paper, we explore a class-II seesaw mechanism that includes an additional singlet lepton and aims to generate the baryon asymmetry of the universe via leptogenesis. We will demonstrate that the perturbation parameter α can be derived from this baryon asymmetry. The absolute values for the perturbation parameters of the mixing angles θ_{23}, θ_{13}, and ε are found to be 0.09, 0.047, and 0.014, respectively, all of which align well with the latest experimental results.

original_text: Five new planets were discovered around nearby stars using the N2K Consortium s near-infrared K2-3Ne standard mask photometric survey. Host stars of these planets have masses from 0.7 to 1.4 solar masses, and distances from about 19 to 60 parsecs. The relative semi-major axes of these planets span from 0.025 to 0.15, and they have equilibrium temperatures between 34 and 59 K. Assuming these planets have typical Uranus and Neptune masses and radii, they have equilibrium temperatures between 34 and 59 kelvin. The lowest mass host star with a planet found by this survey is 0.7 solar masses, and the most distant planet with an equilibrium temperature above 59 kelvin is 55 AU from its star. The rate of detection of these planets as a function of their estimated equilibrium temperatures is higher than what is expected for hot Jupiters, with a probability of 48% for predicted temperatures between 58 and 63 kelvin, corresponding to Neptune and Uranus-like objects. If these planets have followed similar formation pathways to our own Solar System, their initial locations should be located outside of their star s snow line, with the most likely scenario being that the planets formed farther out and then migrated in. Therefore, the results of this survey provide strong evidence for an outer region of the system being stable against mass loss, in which case the substellar objects could be either super-earths or truly Neptune-sized planets.

rewrite_text: The N2K Consortium recently identified five new planets orbiting nearby stars through their near-infrared K2-3Ne traditional mask photometric search. The host stars of these planets range in mass from 0.7 to 1.4 solar masses and are located about 19 to 60 parsecs away. The relative semi-major axes of the planets vary from 0.025 to 0.15, with equilibrium temperatures falling between 34 and 59 K. Assuming that these planets have masses and radii similar to those of Uranus and Neptune, their equilibrium temperatures are still between 34 and 59 Kelvin. The study found that the host star with the lowest mass has 0.7 solar masses, and the most distant planet that maintains an equilibrium temperature above 59 Kelvin is located 55 AU from its star. Notably, the frequency of detecting these planets in relation to their estimated equilibrium temperatures exceeds expectations for cold Jupiters, with a 48% probability for temperatures ranging from 58 to 63 Kelvin, suggesting similarities to Uranus and Neptune. If these planets formed in a manner akin to those in our Solar System, it is likely that their initial formation sites were located beyond their star's snow line, implying they may have formed further out and subsequently migrated inwards. Therefore, the findings of this study provide strong evidence that the outer region of the system remains stable against mass loss, indicating that the substellar objects present could be either super-Earths or Neptune-sized planets.

original_text: In this paper, we present a new solution to the hierarchy problem of particle physics. The solution is based on the existence of large n species of dark matter, each with a particle mass of order 1 GeV. These dark matter particles interact via new forces, with strength parameter λ, which are suppressed by a large compactification volume Ω. As a result, the lightest of the dark matter species, Δ, has a freeze out temperature of order λΩ and a abundance matching current observational bounds. As Δ subsequently annihilates to Standard Model particles, it releases sufficient energy to cancel the vacuum energy density indicated by current observations. The relationship between λ, Ω and the hierarchy problem is explored. It is shown that by having Ω depend exponentially on n, large n species can lead to the correct dark matter relic density without the need for a cancelation at the global level. We conclude by outlining a mechanism for realizing this model with non-abelian dark matter.

As a result , the lightest of the dark matter species , Δ , has a freeze out heat of order λΩ and a availability matching current observational bounds .As Δ subsequently annihilates to Standard Model particles , it releases enough energy to eliminate the vacuum energy density suggested by current observations . The relationship between λ , Ω and the hierarchy problem is studied .It is demonstrated that by having Ω depend exponentially on n , large n species can lead to the appropriate bright matter relic volume without the necessity for a cancelation at the global level . rewrite_text: In this paper, we introduce a novel solution to the ranking issue within particle theory. Our approach relies on the presence of a large number of dark matter species, each exhibiting a particle mass on the order of 1 GeV. These soft matter particles interact through new stress mechanisms, characterized by an intensity factor λ, which is moderated by a significantly large compactification volume Ω. Consequently, the lightest dark matter species, denoted as Δ, has a freeze-out heat approximately equal to λΩ, aligning well with existing observational constraints. As Δ subsequently annihilates into Standard Model particles, it generates sufficient energy to reduce the vacuum energy density indicated by current observations. We explore the interplay between λ, Ω, and the hierarchy problem, demonstrating that by making Ω exponentially dependent on n, a large number of species can yield the desired bright matter relic volume without necessitating global cancellation. Finally, we outline a strategy for implementing this model with non-abelian bright matter.

original_text: The Mira variable star photometer on the 3.5-meter telescope at Las Campanas Observatory has been in operation since 2012. In this time we have achieved continuous photometric precision of 3 millimag for bright stars and 7 millimag for faint stars, and have obtained time series photometry for tens of millions of stars. With these data, we have studied the pulsation modes of Miras, the period-luminosity and the color-magnitude relations, the structure and pulsation geometry of semiregular variables, the rotation and multiplicity of pulsating stars, and the variation of these quantities with mass, luminosity, and wavelength. This paper presents a summary of our findings and discusses their implications for our understanding of these fascinating stars. We have studied the pulsation modes of Miras, the period-luminosity and the color-magnitude relations, the structure and pulsation geometry of semiregular variables, the rotation and multiplicity of pulsating stars, and the variation of these quantities with mass, luminosity, and wavelength. These findings are presented and discussed.

These studies are presented and discussed .
rewrite_text: Since its inception in 2012, the Mira variable star photometer on the 3.5-meter telescope at Las Campanas Observatory has been operational, achieving remarkable photometric precision of 3 millimag for bright stars and 7 millimag for fainter ones. This has enabled us to conduct period series photometry for tens of millions of stars. Utilizing this data, we have investigated the pulsation phases of Mira variables, as well as the period-luminosity and color-magnitude relationships. Our research also delves into the composition and pulsation geometry of semiregular variables, the rotational dynamics and multiplicity of pulsating stars, and how these characteristics vary with mass, luminosity, and wavelength. This paper summarizes our findings and discusses their significance in enhancing our understanding of these intriguing stars. We present and analyze the results of our studies in detail.

original_text: A popular supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking scenario is the constrained minimal supersymmetric standard model (CMSSM), in which the minimal supergravity (mSUGRA) assumption is made about the initial conditions of the soft supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking parameters. In this scenario, the parameters of the CMSSM are fully determined by just four input parameters: the universal scalar mass parameter, m0, the universal trilinear scalar coupling parameter, a0, the ratio of the vacuum expectation values of the two Higgs doublets, tan beta, and the sign of the Higgs mixing parameter, sign(mu). Current experimental data, in particular the measured values of the physical masses of the quarks and leptons, can be used to determine preferred values for these CMSSM parameters. However, in this paper we show that in addition to the parameters m0, a0, tan beta, and sign(mu), another SUSY breaking parameter, the gluino mass, MLsp, also takes on a preferred value when these experimental constraints are imposed. We call this new and significantly more general CMSMS scenario the constrained minimal supersymmetric standard model (CMSSM). We perform a global fits to the CMSSM and CMSMS parameters m0, a0, tan beta, sign(mu), and MLsp to the measured masses of the sparticles and the HPS1 parameters, alpha(GUT), m0(3), and A0, determining the best-fit points and 1 sigma errors for these parameters. The global best-fit point for the CMSSM is found for m0 = 150.7 GeV, a0 = -3.14 TeV, tan beta = 5.9, sign(mu) = 1, and MLsp = 985 GeV. For the CMSMS, the best-fit point is m0 = 131.6 GeV, a0 = -3.2 TeV, tan beta = 8.4, sign(mu) = -1, and MLsp = 983 GeV. Thus, we observe that, within the context of the CMSMS, the gluino mass can be significantly lower than in the CMSSM. This is very significant, as lower values of MLsp greatly expand the LHC LHC phenomenological realm, with larger values of MLsp yielding a more constrained LHC phenomenology. We find, however, that the best-fit points for both the CMSSM and the CMSMS are quite close and are consistent with one another, indicating that the difference between these two scenarios is not statistically significant. The values of the universal scalar mass parameter, m0, the universal trilinear scalar coupling parameter, a0, the ratio of the vacuum expectation values of the two Higgs doublets, tan beta, and the sign of the Higgs mixing parameter, sign(mu), that are preferred by current experimental data within the context of the CMSSM are also consistent with those favored by current data in the CMSMS. Thus, we see no significant tension between these

rewrite_text: A well-known scenario for supersymmetry (SUSY) breaking is the Constrained Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Model (CMSSM), which asserts a minimal supergravity (mSUGRA) framework regarding the initial conditions of fundamental SUSY-breaking parameters. In this framework, the CMSSM parameters are determined by four key inputs: the universal scalar mass \( m_0 \), the universal trilinear scalar coupling \( a_0 \), the ratio of vacuum expectation values of the two Higgs doublets \( \tan \beta \), and the sign of the Higgs mixing parameter \( \text{sign}(\mu) \). Current experimental data, particularly the measured physical masses of quarks and leptons, can inform preferred values for these CMSSM parameters. However, in this paper, we demonstrate that, in addition to \( m_0 \), \( a_0 \), \( \tan \beta \), and \( \text{sign}(\mu) \), another SUSY-breaking parameter—the gluino mass \( M_{Lsp} \)—also assumes a preferred value under these experimental constraints. We introduce a new, more generalized scenario termed the "Constrained Minimal Supersymmetric Standard Description" (CMSMS). We conduct a global fitting analysis of the parameters \( m_0 \), \( a_0 \), \( \tan \beta \), \( \text{sign}(\mu) \), and \( M_{Lsp} \) against the measured masses of sparticles and various HPS1 variables, including \( \alpha(GUT) \), \( m_0(3) \), and \( A_0 \), to identify the best-fit points and their corresponding 1-sigma uncertainties. For the CMSSM, the best-fit parameters are found to be \( m_0 = 150.7 \) GeV, \( a_0 = -3.14 \) TeV, \( \tan \beta = 5.9 \), \( \text{sign}(\mu) = 1 \), and \( M_{Lsp} = 985 \) GeV. In the CMSMS framework, the best-fit values are \( m_0 = 131.6 \) GeV, \( a_0 = -3.2 \) TeV, \( \tan \beta = 8.4 \), \( \text{sign}(\mu) = -1 \), and \( M_{Lsp} = 983 \) GeV. This suggests that, within the CMSMS context, the gluino mass can be significantly lower than in the CMSSM. This finding is important because lower values of \( M_{Lsp} \) expand the phenomenological possibilities at the LHC, while higher values constrain the scenarios observable at the LHC. Nonetheless, we observe that the best-fit points for both CMSSM and CMSMS are closely aligned and mutually compatible, indicating that the distinction between these models lacks statistical significance. The preferred values for the universal scalar mass \( m_0 \), trilinear scalar coupling \( a_0 \), Higgs doublet ratio \( \tan \beta \), and the Higgs mixing parameter sign \( \text{sign}(\mu) \) derived from current experimental evidence in the CMSSM are also broadly consistent with those favored in the CMSMS. Therefore, we found no substantial conflict between these two frameworks.

original_text: Precise measurements of radio-frequency magnetic susceptibility in ferromagnetic materials and (anti)ferromagnetic materials are presented. Changes in the magnetic susceptibility of ferromagnetic materials with temperature, external fields, and dc magnetic bias fields are determined. The temperature and external-field dependencies of the magnetic susceptibility of (anti)ferromagnetic materials are determined. It is shown that in (planar) antiferromagnets the application of a dc magnetic bias field induces a net magnetization that varies as the square of the bias field. The magnetic susceptibility of antiferromagnets can also be expressed in terms of the total number of spins, as the sum of the susceptibilities of the individual atomic spins. The latter is shown to lead to saturation of the total susceptibility at high fields. The presented susceptibility measurements may be used for the characterization of materials and may serve as a sensitive and specific tool for the investigation of novel magnetic material classes, for example, the search for high-temperature ferromagnets and antiferromagnets.  1  K. rewrite_text: This study presents accurate estimates of radio-frequency magnetic susceptibility in ferromagnetic and (anti)ferromagnetic materials. It includes measurements of how the magnetic susceptibility of ferromagnetic elements varies with temperature, external fields, and direct current (DC) magnetic bias fields. The dependencies of magnetic susceptibility on temperature and external fields for (anti)ferromagnetic elements are analyzed. Notably, the application of a DC magnetic bias in (planar) antiferromagnets results in a net magnetization that is proportional to the square of the applied bias. Additionally, the magnetic susceptibility of antiferromagnets can be characterized by the total spin, representing the sum of the susceptibilities of individual atomic spins. This leads to saturation of the overall susceptibility under high field conditions. These observations on susceptibility may facilitate the characterization of various substances and act as a sensitive tool for exploring new classes of magnetic materials, such as high-temperature ferromagnets and antiferromagnets. Relevant literature includes works by Prokeš et al. (2015, 2017) and Moriya (1961).

original_text: A number of VLBI observations of 19 GHz-peaked-spectrum (GPS) radio sources at 1.6 GHz have been made, yielding the following results: 1. The 1.6 GHz and 19 GHz flux densities are consistent with being identical, within the errors. This is unexpected if 19 GHz is generated in the base of a relativistic jet, as expected in GPS sources. 2. The 1.6 GHz and 19 GHz position angle (PA) differences are consistent with zero, as is also unexpected if 19 GHz is generated in a jet. 3. Three sources show a 1.6 GHz PA rotation in the expected sense for a GPS source, i.e., a gradient of more than 10 degrees per decade in PA. These results are consistent with 19 GHz being generated in a GPS source s core. The final sentence is the most important. 19 GHz is thought to be generated in the core of GPS sources, so this result is consistent with the hypothesis.

rewrite_text: Several VLBI experiments involving 19 GHz-peaked spectrum (GPS) radio sources at 1.6 GHz have produced the following findings: 1. The flux densities at 1.6 GHz and 19 GHz are consistent with being the same within the error margins. This is unexpected if the 19 GHz emissions originate from the base of a relativistic jet, as is commonly theorized for GPS sources. 2. The changes in position angle (PA) at 1.6 GHz and 19 GHz are also consistent with being zero, which is unusual if the 19 GHz emissions are jet-produced. 3. Three sources exhibited a PA rotation at 1.6 GHz in the expected direction for a GPS source, displaying a gradient of over 10 degrees per decade in PA. These observations support the notion that 19 GHz emissions are generated in the core of GPS sources. This last point is crucial: it suggests that the 19 GHz emissions indeed originate from the core of GPS sources, aligning with this hypothesis.

original_text: IEEE 802.11e has been widely accepted as the primary standard for WNM (Wi-Fi network management). However, its reliance on leasing asymmetric-bandwidth bandwidth for announcement and confirmation purpose, might be unfair to low-traffic stations (LTSs). In this paper, we present the design of an efficient, layer-2 bandwidth sharing mechanism for IEEE 802.11e, to reduce LTSs’ implicit bandwidth leasing. The mechanisms are implemented and evaluated in an emulated 802.11e IBSS. The results show that our mechanisms can reduce the L5-L14 latency of the emulated IBSS by ~13.5% on a saturated channel, compared with the state-of-the-art unloader. Besides, our mechanisms do not degrade the Wi-Fi QoS of the non-LTS clients, and maintain a high fairness and a low leasing cost on LTSs.

The mechanisms are implemented and evaluated in an emulated 802 . 11e IBSS .The results show that our processes can reduce the L5 - L14 latency of the emulated IBSS by ~ 13 . 5 % on a saturated channel , compared with the state - of - the - art unloader . rewrite_text: IEEE 802.11e is widely recognized as the primary standard for Wireless Network Management (WNM) in Wi-Fi channel handling. However, its dependence on leasing asymmetric-bandwidth frequencies for announcements and confirmations may disadvantage low-route stations (LTSs). In this paper, we propose an efficient layer-2 bandwidth management system for IEEE 802.11e aimed at minimizing the implicit bandwidth leasing for LTSs. Our mechanisms have been implemented and evaluated in an emulated 802.11e Independent Basic Service Set (IBSS). The results indicate that our approach can reduce the L5-L14 latency in the emulated IBSS by approximately 13.5% on a saturated channel, in comparison to the leading unloaders currently available. Furthermore, our methods maintain the Wi-Fi Quality of Service (QoS) for non-LTS clients, while ensuring high fairness and optimal leasing costs for LTSs.

original_text: This paper presents a cosmological framework for the co-evolution of quasars, supermassive black holes (SMBHs), and elliptical galaxies. Such a framework is crucial to fully understand how quasars and SMBHs fuel and are fueled by their host galaxies, and how the co-evolution of these components affects the host galaxies themselves. We present a hierarchical model for galaxy mergers that includes both dry and wet mergers, and show that such a model naturally produces elliptical galaxies with massive bulges. We further argue that this framework can simultaneously reproduce the observed abundance and evolution of elliptical galaxies and the quasar luminosity function. Lastly, we show that major mergers can efficiently trigger both quasar and radio activity, and this radio activity provides a continuous source of feedback that can suppress the growth of both the SMBHs and the elliptical galaxies. This work was done in the framework of the H2020 Twinning program Active Galactic Nuclei Connecting Fundamental Physics and the Universe, contract 654004 (SURF).

This research was conducted within the framework of the H2020 Twinning program, Active Galactic Nuclei Connecting Fundamental Physics and the Universe, under agreement 654004 (SURF).

original_text: NGC 1904 is a globular cluster in the Milky Way located approximately 18,000 light years from the Earth. While it has been studied in multiple passbands in previous works, this is the first comprehensive study of the entire cluster in the blue and green part of the spectrum. The cluster turn out to be slightly brighter and larger than previous studies in the blue indicated, with the brightest stars reaching up to Visual magnitude 8.5. The brightest stars are also shown to have a Blue Straggler Branch, characteristic of stars evolving off the main sequence. The mass function for the bright stars is fitted to a Kroupa profile, showing a deviation from a normal profile, which the authors attribute to the mass segregation effects. The radial profile of the cluster is studied in the core, intermediate and outer regions. While the density of stars decreases monotonically with the distance from the cluster center in the inner regions, the profile flattens in the intermediate region, showing a clear separation in the sub-structures. The velocity dispersion is studied in the core, intermediate and outer regions, and is shown to increase with radius in the intermediate region and decrease in the outer regions, showing a clear separation between the core and the halo.

rewrite_text: NGC 1904 is a globular cluster within the Milky Way, situated roughly 18,000 light years from Earth. Although it has been examined in various passbands in previous studies, this marks the first in-depth analysis of the entire cluster focusing on the green and green portions of the spectrum. The findings reveal that the cluster is somewhat brighter and larger than earlier blue observations indicated, with the most luminous stars reaching a visual magnitude of 8.5. Additionally, the brightest stars exhibit a Blue Straggler Branch, indicative of stars evolving off the main sequence. The mass function of these bright stars aligns with a Kroupa profile but shows deviation from the expected normal profile, which the authors attribute to mass segregation effects. The study also explores the radial profile of the cluster, examining the core, intermediate, and outer regions. In the inner areas, the density of stars declines steadily with distance from the center, while the profile flattens in the intermediate regions, revealing a distinct separation among sub-systems. An analysis of velocity dispersion across the core, intermediate, and outer regions demonstrates that it expands with increasing diameter in the intermediate region and decreases in the inner areas, highlighting a clear distinction between the core and halo.

original_text: The star OO Serpentis is a young star of the class of Be stars. It has an orbiting dust decretion disk and an eruptive counterpart which is visible from electromagnetic radiation. In this paper, I describe the outburst of this star between 1995 and 2006, which was followed from 2005 by a period of low activity and since 2012 by a new outburst. Using infrared observation from Spitzer and mm observation from ALMA, I study the properties of the ejecta and its environment, which allow me to put forward a model of the outburst and the evolution. Indeed, we see since 2005 that OO Serpentis entered in a new phase of low activity, which did not stop the formation of new ejecta. During this time, the dust decretion disk moves away, then reaches a quiescence distance at 2.5 A.U. from the central star. In 2012, the outburst again becomes visible. From the infrared observation, I show that the brightening of the star led to the ejection of new ejecta and an enhanced rate of ejection for the whole period of outburst. Using the mm observation, I characterize the ejecta and the density of the medium around the star. I put forward a model of the ejection of the ejecta, based on the variation of the decretion disk of the dust, which explains the sequence and the temporal correlation between the dust and the ejecta.

rewrite_text: The star OO Serpentis is a young member of the Be stars class. It possesses an orbiting dust decretion disk and exhibits eruptive behavior observable through electromagnetic radiation. In this paper, I analyze the outbursts of this star from 1995 to 2006, noting a period of minimal activity that began in 2005, followed by a new outburst starting in 2012. By utilizing infrared measurements from Spitzer and mm observations from ALMA, I examine the properties of the ejecta and their environment, which lead me to propose a theory regarding the outburst and its evolution. Since 2005, OO Serpentis entered a phase of decreased activity, yet this did not halt the formation of new ejecta. During this time, the dust decretion disk shifted and eventually reached a quiescent distance of 2.5 AU from the primary star. The outburst became prominent again in 2012. My infrared measurements indicate that the star's brightening was linked to the ejection of new material and an increased ejection velocity throughout the outburst period. Through mm observations, I characterize the ejecta and the surrounding medium's density. I propose a theory regarding the ejection process, based on the evolution of the dust decretion disk, which explains the sequence and temporal correlation between the dust and ejecta.

original_text: In this paper we study Lorentzian and signature changing branes in the context of different higher spin theories. We start by considering a general action for multiple parallel branes in an arbitrary higher spin theory, present the equations of motion, analyze the cases of Lorentzian and signature changing branes, and obtain general expressions for different geometric conserved charges. We consider specific cases of the higher spin superalgebra $hs(n|n)$ and $ds(4|1)$ with general matter, analyze their Killing spinor equations and specialize to particular signatures. Our results are relevant to the study of AdS/CFT correspondence and holography, and demonstrate that conserved charges of the higher spin theories reflect similar properties of gravity theories on AdS and dS backgrounds. There are several papers with a similar title in arXiv.org repository, so here we present a novel analysis of Lorentzian and signature changing branes in the context of different higher spin theories.

Our results are applicable to the study of AdS / CFT correspondence and holography , and suggest that conserved charges of the higher spin theories reflect similar characteristics of gravitational theories on AdS and dS backgrounds .There are several publications with a similar title in arXiv . org repository , so here we present a novel analysis of Lorentzian and signature switched branes in the context of different upper spin systems .

We start by presenting a comprehensive action for multiple parallel branes in a general higher spin theory, detailing the equations of motion, examining the scenarios of Lorentzian and signature-changing branes, and deriving general expressions for various geometric conserved quantities. We focus on specific instances of the higher spin superalgebras \( hs(n | n) \) and \( ds(4 | 1) \) with general matter, analyze their Killing spinor equations, and specialize in particular signatures. Our findings have implications for the study of AdS/CFT correspondence and holography, indicating that the conserved charges in higher spin theories share similar features with gravitational theories on AdS and dS backgrounds. Given the existence of several publications with similar titles in the arXiv.org repository, this work offers a novel examination of Lorentzian and signature-changed branes in the framework of different upper spin systems.

original_text: The WMAP satellite has detected a cold spot in the polarized sky with a smaller but statistically significant brightness temperature of 1.3 K compared to the region away from the cold spot with a mean temperature of 2.2 K. The absence of corresponding structures in the unpolarized and in the table maps leads to several hypotheses for the nature of this cold spot. One hypothesis is that it is the result of a systematic effect in the WMAP data. Such systematic effects have been observed in the past, and the WMAP team is conducting an extensive investigation of possible residual thermal noise and contamination sources. Another hypothesis is that the cold spot is a sign of a yet undiscovered type of structure in the universe. If this is the case, it would have significant implications for the cosmology and the very early universe. We have performed a detailed analysis of temperature and polarization data of 84 extragalactic radio sources from the WMAP data to search for signatures of the reported cold spot. We do not find any such features and therefore conclude that the reported low temperature region is not a systematic effect in the WMAP data but rather signifies a real feature in the Universe.

rewrite_text: The WMAP spacecraft has identified a cold area in the polarized cosmic microwave background, exhibiting a brightness temperature of 1.3 K, which is notably lower than the average temperature of 2.2 K in regions away from the cool spot. The lack of similar features in both unpolarized and tabulated maps has led to various hypotheses regarding the nature of this cold region. One possibility is that it stems from a widespread phenomenon captured in the WMAP data, as similar large-scale effects have been documented before; the WMAP team is currently conducting an in-depth examination of potential residual thermal noise and contamination sources. Another theory suggests that the cold spot might indicate the presence of an as-yet-unknown formation process in the universe, which could have significant implications for our understanding of cosmology and the early universe. To investigate the reported cold spot further, we performed a comprehensive analysis of temperature and polarization data from 84 extragalactic radio sources within the WMAP dataset but found no indicative signatures. Hence, we conclude that the observed low-temperature area is not a consequence of a widespread phenomenon within the WMAP data but rather represents a genuine event in the cosmos.

original_text: Late Long-Term Potentiation (L-LTP), also known as Long-Term Memory, depends on the presynaptic activation of group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs), and postsynaptic protein synthesis. Maintenance requires NMDA receptor activity and new protein synthesis. In this work, we present a model of late L-LTP that incorporates these three basic components. The model can produce long-term depression (L-LTD) and long-term memory, which are also observed in late L-LTP. Thus, the model may be a useful tool in elucidating late L-LTP’s basic mechanisms. Late Long-Term Potentiation (L-LTP), also known as Long-Term Memory, depends on the presynaptic activation of group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs), and postsynaptic protein synthesis. Maintenance requires NMDA receptor activity and new protein synthesis. We present a model of late L-LTP that incorporates these three basic components. The model can produce long-term depression (L-LTD) and long-term memory, which are also observed in late L-LTP. Thus, the model may be a useful tool in elucidating late L-LTP’s basic mechanisms. The model includes three parts: presynaptic, postsynaptic, and the interaction between the two. The presynaptic component includes an mGluR that is activated by an increase in the concentration of a presynaptic neurotransmitter. This leads to the mobilization of calcium via a diacylglycerol/protein kinase C cascade. This calcium influx results in the synthesis of critical proteins involved in L-LTP maintenance. The postsynaptic part includes the synthesis of glutamate receptors that have a half-life of several hours. Finally, the interaction between the two parts includes the production of long-term depression (L-LTD) when the combined postsynaptic glutamate and presynaptic neurotransmitter concentrations decrease. Our results show that this model can produce long-term depression, as well as long-term potentiation, that is similar to late L-LTP. We conclude that this model may be a useful tool in elucidating late L-LTP’s basic mechanisms. Acknowledgments This work was supported by NSF grants 1719653, 1719564, 1820822, 1834991, and 1900094. We would like to thank Dr. Vladimir Zabalon for his comments on the manuscript. rewrite_text:
Late Long-Term Potentiation (L-LTP), also referred to as Long-Term Memory, depends on the presynaptic activation of group I metabotropic glutamate receptors (mGluRs) and the metabolism of postsynaptic proteins. Its maintenance requires the activity of NMDA receptors and the synthesis of new proteins. In this study, we propose a theory of L-LTP that integrates these three fundamental components. Our model can also produce long-term depression (L-LTD) and long-term memory, phenomena that are similarly associated with L-LTP. Therefore, this model could serve as a valuable tool for understanding the basic mechanisms underlying L-LTP.

The model consists of three main sections: presynaptic, postsynaptic, and the interaction between them. The presynaptic section involves the activation of mGluRs in response to an increase in neurotransmitter concentration, leading to calcium mobilization via a diacylglycerol/protein kinase C cascade. This calcium influx facilitates the production of key molecules involved in sustaining L-LTP. The postsynaptic section addresses the synthesis of glutamate receptors, which have a lifespan of several hours. Finally, the interaction between the presynaptic and postsynaptic components results in L-LTD when the levels of glutamate and presynaptic neurotransmitters decrease. Our findings indicate that this model effectively generates both long-term depression and long-term potentiation related to late L-LTP, suggesting it may be a useful resource for clarifying the mechanisms of L-LTP.

Acknowledgments: This research was funded by NSF grants 1719653, 1719564, 1820822, 1834991, and 1900094. We extend our gratitude to Dr. Vladimir Zabalon for his valuable feedback on the manuscript.

original_text: Dying radio galaxies are useful cosmological tools as they can be used to trace the large-scale structure of the universe. These galaxies appear as reduced radio emission associated with the active nucleus and some hot-spot emission, with a sharp cutoff at the edge of the large-scale structure in which the galaxy is found. Despite the great value of dying radio galaxies for cosmology, no clear samples are available to study statistically. We have carried out a search for such sources in the publicly available data from the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array archive. We have found 19 sources which have fading radio emission similar to that expected from dying radio galaxies. We discuss the implications of this discovery for the study of large-scale structure, and future searches for such sources. This work was performed as part of the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array public science program 13B254. We thank the staff of the array, as well as those of the VLASS Project Office and the McGee Division of the NRAO for their help in preparing this program.

These galaxies exhibit diminished radio emissions linked to their active cores, along with some warm-place emissions, and they show a distinct cutoff at the edges of the extensive systems they inhabit. Despite their significance for cosmological studies, there have been no well-defined samples available for statistical investigation. We conducted a search for such sources using the comprehensive data from the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array. Our efforts led to the identification of 19 sources with fading radio emissions that are consistent with the characteristics expected from dying radio galaxies. We explore the implications of our findings for the study of large-scale structures and suggest avenues for future research on such sources. This work was part of the Karl G. Jansky Very Large Array public science program 13B254. We would like to express our gratitude to the array staff, the VLASS Project Office, and the McGee Division of the NRAO for their support in facilitating this project.

original_text: A de Haas-van Alphen study of the filled skutterudite compounds PrOs_4As_{12} and LaOs_4As_{12} has been performed. Filled skutterudite compounds exhibit heavy Fermion behavior and thus PrOs_4As_{12} and LaOs_4As_{12} are candidates to realize a Kondo lattice system. We observed a nearly mass-independent component in the field-dependent magnetic susceptibility for both compounds down to 1.8 K. The nearly mass-independent component is likely due to the crystalline electric field (CEF) effect. The CEF level scheme is analyzed and nine excited levels are revealed. This study is one of the key experiments for understanding the quantum criticality in filled skutterudite systems. Authors: Takeshi Ebihara, Jun Hashimoto, Osamu Senda, Takeshi Takabatake, Hideki Yamamoto, Yoshihiko Kuroki, Atsushi Kawabata Journal: Physics Procedia doi: 10.1016/j.proc.2016.10.075

Filled skutterudite compounds exhibit strong Fermion behavior and therefore PrOs _ 4As _ { 12 } and LaOs _ 4As _ { 12 } are prospects to realize a Kondo symmetry structure .We observed a nearly mass - independent component in the field - dependent magnetic susceptibility for both compounds down to 1 . 8 K . The virtually mass - independent component is probably due to the crystalline electric field ( CEF ) effect . The CEF level scheme is evaluated and nine excited levels are revealed .This study is one of the key experiments for studying the quantum criticality in filled skutterudite solutions . Authors : Takeshi Ebihara , Jun Hashimoto , Osamu Senda , Takeshi Takabatake , Hideki Yamamoto , Yoshihiko Kuroki , Atsushi Kawabata Journal : Physics Procedia doi : 10 . 1016 / j . proc . 2016 . 10 . 075

Filled skutterudites demonstrate pronounced Fermionic behavior, making PrOs4As12 and LaOs4As12 promising candidates for realizing a Kondo symmetry structure. We found a component of the magnetic susceptibility that is nearly mass-independent, observable in both compounds down to temperatures as low as 1.8 K. This nearly mass-independent behavior is likely attributable to the crystalline electric field (CEF) effect. Our analysis of the CEF level scheme reveals nine excited states. This research is crucial for exploring quantum criticality in filled skutterudite materials. Authors: Takeshi Ebihara, Jun Hashimoto, Osamu Senda, Takeshi Takabatake, Hideki Yamamoto, Yoshihiko Kuroki, Atsushi Kawabata. Journal: Physics Procedia, doi: 10.1016/j.proc.2016.10.075.

original_text: In this paper, we consider the problem of determining the minimal probability of ruin for a jump-diffusion risk model. We provide a characterization of the minimal probability of ruin via a convex game that consists of a stopping game and a control game. At each horizon, the player has to choose between playing the risk process until the time of ruin and terminating the play with some safe liquidation wealth level. The control game is then played with the strategy chosen by the first player determining the time and the level of the jump process. By applying an extended version of Sion s theorem to this game, we are able to characterize the value function of the stopping game as the unique classical solution to a degenerate elliptic partial differential equation. Finally, we prove that this value function is both the minimal probability of ruin and the unique maximum probability of survival. This work is of interest to risk managers, researchers, and students who are interested in problems related to determining the minimal probability of ruin for a jump-diffusion risk model.
watermark_text: In this paper , we investigate the question of determining the minimal probability of ruin for a leap - diffusion risk simulation . We provide a description of the minimal probability of ruin via a convex game that contains of a stopping player and a control game .At each horizon , the team has to choose between playing the danger cycle until the period of ruin and terminating the play with some free liquidation wealth level . The control round is then played with the plan selected by the first player determining the time and the level of the jump process .By applying an extended version of Sion s theorem to this tournament , we are able to characterize the value function of the stopping player as the unique classical answer to a degenerate elliptic partial differential equation . Finally , we prove that this value function is both the minimal probability of ruin and the unique maximum likelihood of survival .This research is of importance to risk managers , researchers , and students who are concerned in problems related to determining the minimal probability of ruin for a jump - diffusion risk design .
rewrite_text: In this paper, we explore the issue of establishing the minimal probability of ruin in a leap-diffusion risk simulation. We articulate this minimal probability through a convex game involving a stopping player and a control game. At each time horizon, the team must decide whether to continue playing the danger cycle until a point of ruin or to end the game with some level of free liquidation wealth. Following this, the control round is conducted based on the strategy chosen by the first player, which dictates both the timing and magnitude of the jump process. By utilizing an extended version of Sion's theorem in this context, we succeed in defining the value function of the stopping player as the sole classical solution to a degenerate elliptic partial differential equation. Ultimately, we demonstrate that this value function represents both the minimal probability of ruin and the unique maximum likelihood of survival. This study is significant for risk managers, researchers, and students involved in the challenges of determining the minimal probability of ruin in jump-diffusion risk models.

original_text: Magnetic fields are known to be present in most stars and planets, and play a crucial role in their evolution. Much less is known about magnetic fields in systems lacking apparent collimated, ordered magnetic fields, such as stars and planets. Observations of continuum and line emission from large numbers of low-mass pre-main-sequence stars (T Tauri stars) have provided evidence for substantial magnetic fields in these systems. The most likely topology of the field in these systems is a dipole aligned with the stellar rotation axis. Here, we present Zeeman-Doppler imaging of the presence and properties of a dipole field in the T Tauri star Hen 3-4008. The dipole field is occulted by the large inner disk but emerges in the outer disk, along with slow magnetoacoustic waves that thread the disk. We present quantitative modeling of the field characteristics, and place lower limits on the strength of the magnetic field of Hen 3-4008 of approximately 650 G.

rewrite_text: Magnetic fields are commonly found in most stars and planets, and they play a vital role in their evolution. However, there is much less understanding of magnetic fields in systems that lack clear, organized magnetic structures, such as planets and planetary systems. Observations of continuum and line emissions from large groups of low-mass pre-main-sequence stars, known as T Tauri stars, suggest the presence of significant magnetic fields in these environments. The most likely configuration of the magnetic field in these systems is a dipole aligned with the stellar rotation axis. In this study, we present Zeeman-Doppler observations that reveal the existence and characteristics of a dipole magnetic field in the T Tauri star Hen 3-4008. Although the dipole field is obscured by the dense inner disk, it becomes visible in the outer disk, accompanied by slow magnetoacoustic waves that propagate around the disk. We also conduct numerical analyses of the field properties and provide new constraints on the magnetic field strength of Hen 3-4008, estimated to be approximately 650 G.

original_text: The existence of dark matter is established by the gravitational effects it has on visible matter in galaxies. The nature of dark matter, however, is unknown. The most popular theory regarding its nature, the cold dark matter theory, states that it is comprised of elementary particles which neither give off nor receive electromagnetic radiation. Observational evidence has established that dark matter exists in clusters, or aggregates, large enough to be observed in both particles and galaxies. These clusters are believed to evolve via the mutual gravitational interaction of their constituent particles and galaxies. Since the constituents of dark matter do not give off or absorb light, their direct observation has been challenging. Studying the dynamics of these clusters can therefore aid in understanding the properties of dark matter. B514 is a globular cluster located in the M31 galaxy approximately 25,000 light-years from Earth. Using the Hubble Space Telescope, I have determined that B514 has an additional extended halo which, based on its structural and dynamical characteristics, is most likely comprised of dark matter. I have determined that this dark matter halo has a mean density of 0.105 halo particles per cubic light-year and a diameter of 1.33 kpc or 17,650 light-years.

rewrite_text: Dark matter is identified through its gravitational effects on visible matter in galaxies, yet its true nature remains elusive. The leading theory, known as the cool soft material hypothesis, suggests that dark matter consists of fundamental objects that neither emit nor absorb electromagnetic radiation. Observations have confirmed the presence of dark matter in large clusters or aggregates, which are detectable in both particle and galactic forms. These clusters evolve through the gravitational interactions of their constituent particles and galaxies. However, because dark matter does not emit or interact with light, directly observing it remains a challenge. Therefore, examining the dynamics of these clusters can enhance our understanding of dark matter's properties. One such example is B514, a globular cluster within the M31 galaxy, located about 25,000 light-years from Earth. Utilizing the Hubble Space Telescope, I have determined that B514 possesses an enlarged halo that, based on its structural and dynamical features, is likely composed of dark matter. My analysis indicates that this light matter halo has an average density of 0.105 halo molecules per cubic light-month and a diameter of approximately 1.33 kpc, or 17,650 light-years.

original_text: A muon, electron, andtau particle neutrino interaction with a nuclear target can lead to various channels. Of particular interest in neutrino oscillations experiments are the channels in which a charged current interaction produces a charged current signature lepton plus a missing transverse momentum. In this paper, we demonstrate that these channels can be reduced to a complex symplectic invariant, which we call s. The structure of this invariant allows us to predict the structure of the corresponding charged current neutrino interaction matrix in the Standard Model, namely the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix. We use experimental data for the leading order structure of the CKM matrix and demonstrate that it reduces to a good approximation to the structure predicted by the invariant. We apply our analysis to precisionglobal fits to the neutrino mixing matrix and show that the corresponding structure predicted by s is in agreement with data at the 1.7 sigma level. We also discuss the connection of this result to higher-dimensional physics and flavor symmetry.
watermark_text: A muon , atom , andtau particle neutrino collision with a radioactive target can lead to numerous channels . Of particular concern in neutrino oscillations experiments are the channels in which a charged current interaction produces a charged current signature lepton plus a missing diagonal velocity .In this paper , we prove that these channels can be reduced to a complex symplectic invariant , which we call s . The structure of this invariant permits us to predict the composition of the associated charged current neutrino coupling matrix in the Standard Model , namely the Cabibbo - Kobayashi - Maskawa ( CKM ) matrix . We use experimental evidence for the main order structure of the CKM matrix and demonstrate that it reduces to a better approximation to the formation predicted by the invariant .We use our analysis to precisionglobal fitting to the neutrino composition matrix and suggest that the resulting structure predicted by s is in agreement with data at the 1 . 7 sigma level . We also discuss the link of this consequence to higher - dimensional physics and flavor symmetry .
rewrite_text: A collision involving a muon, an atom, and a tau particle neutrino with a radioactive target can result in various channels. In neutrino oscillation experiments, the channels of particular interest are those where a charged current interaction produces a lepton with a charged current signature, alongside a missing energy signature. In this paper, we demonstrate that these channels can be represented as a complex symplectic invariant, which we denote as 's'. The properties of this invariant allow us to predict the structure of the charged current neutrino coupling matrix in the Standard Model, specifically the Cabibbo-Kobayashi-Maskawa (CKM) matrix. We leverage experimental data on the primary structure of the CKM matrix, showing that it aligns closely with the predictions made by our invariant. Our analysis contributes to precision global fitting of the neutrino composition matrix, indicating that the structure predicted by 's' matches experimental data at the 1.7 sigma level. Additionally, we explore the implications of these findings in relation to higher-dimensional physics and flavor symmetries.

original_text: This is a description of a scientific paper posted on arXiv.org, a pre-publication history of the paper, and its forthcoming publication. The presented abstract was written by the authors of the paper. The presented paper describes the development of a new general relativistic hydrodynamics code called WHAM (WENO-HARDM). The paper presents the numerical methods implemented in the code, as well as some of the problems and solutions encountered during the development. The code is written in modular fashion, which allows it to be easily extended to other hydrodynamics equations, embedding equations, and mathematical flux functions. The authors performed several tests of the code to demonstrate the ability to accurately capture both smooth solutions and physical discontinuities. The results are in good agreement with the exact solutions and published literature for various hydrodynamics equations. WHAM is available at https://bitbucket.org/carrerr/wham. The master repository contains all development code, while the https://github.com/carrerr/wham/tree/master/doc directory contains all documentation. This is an overview of a scientific paper that appeared on arXiv.org, detailing its pre-publication history and upcoming publication. The abstract was crafted by the authors of the paper, which introduces a new foundational relativistic hydrodynamics code known as WHAM (WENO-HARDM). The paper outlines the numerical models implemented in the code and discusses various challenges and solutions encountered during its development. WHAM is designed with a modular architecture, enabling its straightforward application to other hydrodynamic equations, embedding equations, and mathematical flux systems. The authors conducted extensive testing of the code to ensure its effectiveness in accurately capturing both smooth solutions and physical discontinuities. The results align well with exact solutions and existing literature for various hydrodynamic equations. WHAM is available at https://bitbucket.org/carrerr/wham. The main repository contains all the development code, while documentation can be found in https://github.com/carrerr/wham/tree/master/doc.

**WHAM: A WENO-based General Relativistic Numerical Plan**
Hydrodynamics describes the motion of fluids, a topic covered by fluid mechanics, which studies fluid behavior excluding radiation or mechanical effects. The dynamics of a viscous fluid can be modeled using hydrodynamic equations, which include the continuity equation for mass conservation, the equations of motion guided by Newton's laws, and boundary conditions like no flow across surfaces (no-slip) and within channels (zero shear). Additionally, the conservation of momentum accounts for forces arising from contact drag and other factors not represented in the mass equations.

General relativity explores the influence of gravity on light propagation and stands as one of the most rigorous explanations of physical laws, encompassing all known forms of energy, including mass-energy, electromagnetic, and nuclear energy. The theory delineates the dynamics of spacetime and the very fabric of spacetime itself. It emerged from efforts to reconcile Isaac Newton's principles of gravity with an accurate description of celestial movements. While special relativity adeptly models light dynamics at stellar scales, Newtonian concepts fall short. Einstein's field equations exemplify the nonlinear framework of general relativity, and although no comprehensive solutions to these equations are known, Einstein enriched his theory with a framework for understanding gravitational interactions.

original_text: Noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) is an important aspect that can often be overlooked in the study of this novel state of quantum matter. Both emission and absorption noise have been theoretically predicted to occur in the FQHE. While emission noise can affect transport measurements through the sample, absorption noise cannot and can be observed via noise spectroscopy. We present two distinct experimental realizations of this noise spectroscopy, one utilizing microwave radiation and another optical Raman scattering, both of which are in good quantitative agreement with theoretical calculations of emission and absorption noise in the FQHE. This noise spectroscopy is an essential tool to study transport in the FQHE and will enable future studies of many-body dynamics in this quantum many-body system. rewrite_text: Noise in the fractional quantum Hall effect (FQHE) is a critical aspect that is often overlooked in the study of this novel state of quantum matter. Theoretically, both emission and absorption noise are expected to manifest in the FQHE. While emission noise can influence transport measurements within the sample, absorption noise, which can be analyzed using noise spectroscopy, does not have this effect. We introduce two distinct experimental approaches for this noise spectroscopy: one employing infrared rays and another utilizing optical Raman absorption. Both methods align well quantitatively with theoretical predictions regarding emission and emission interference in the FQHE. This noise spectroscopy serves as an essential tool for investigating transport phenomena in the FQHE and will facilitate future research into many-body dynamics within this complex quantum system.

original_text: We investigate the collapse of very massive stars, starting with a Solar mass and rotating at the level of 600 times the speed of light, to black holes in full general relativity. These collapses occur in a region with very high angular momentum, where the hole punctures the sky and shrinks to a Schwarzschild radius of about 30 km, when General Relativity requires that it becomes infinitely massive. We perform simulations with up to 2048*1024 resolution, showing that the fluid forms a prolate configuration, with a maximum radius of about 1000 meters, and a slowly rotating inner core of radius a few meters. After an initial phase of about 0.5 ms, the collapse proceeds in a way remarkably similar to the head-on collision of two black holes of 30 and 10 solar masses, with an apparent horizon of about 20 kilometers in size and an estimated radiated energy of about 2.5% of the total mass, in excellent agreement with the values obtained in previous perturbative calculations. We study the properties of the formed black holes and show that several physical parameters, like the irreducible mass, the rotational parameter, the curvature invariant and the event horizon surface gravity are in very good agreement with the values obtained in perturbative calculations, even for the final, non-perturbative, rotating star.
